loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To build a new lavatory for the family.

loan.name: Dul

texts.en: Dul K., 20, is married and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has been raising pigs to earn a living, making US$4 per day, while her husband, growing rice crops and selling them to the local market, earns approximately US$4.5 per day. Currently, Dul K. would like to take out a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a generator to start a battery charging business. She believes that the new business will provide her family with additional income.

loan.use: Purchase of a generator

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to support her current business

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: Hire of a farm worker to help harvest output and plow farmland

loan.name: Phorn

texts.en: Mrs. Phorn S. is a 21-year-old who makes a living raising pigs, which she sells after 6 months time for slaughter. She started this over 3 years ago. She lives in Rokat Commune in Pursat Province. Phorn is married to Mr. Nang Kun, 26 years old, who is a farmer who specializes in rice crop. Phorn has planned to improve her business, so she would like to request a loan of $500 to buy more female pigs to make piglets for breeding, and to decorate a pigpen with the rest.

loan.use: To buy more female pigs

loan.name: Sath

texts.en: Mr. Sath T. is a villager in Preak Thom village in Kandal Province. He makes Khmer noodle. He is a 60 year old widow and the father of five children. Two of his children help in his business, another is a motorbike driver, and the other two are attending the local school. Even though they have different businesses, they do not have much money to fix the house. Thus, Mr. Sath T. decided to ask for a loan to repair his house so that his family members will live in better conditions.

loan.use: To repair his house so that his family members live in better conditions.

loan.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. is 27 years old. She has 2 children. Her husband is a welder. She has been in TYM since 2003. Now her main income is from selling gas and gas stoves. Besides, her family has some money from her husband's salary. That is why the familyâ€™s income is very stable. This time she wants to borrow 20 million VND ($1,175 US) to invest in her business.

loan.use: To invest in her gas stove business.

loan.name: Zokir

texts.en: Zokir M. is a hard-working man who strives every day to provide for his entire family, which consists of his wife and three children. He manages a grocery store where he sells many staples, such as bread, juice, sweets, and other preserved foods. Having started this business only three years ago with less than $100, Zokir has attracted a strong base of customers who are impressed by his efforts to travel to neighboring cities to purchase especially valuable items. In order to purchase additional foodstuffs and increase his inventory, Zokir is requesting a loan of $750.

loan.use: To purchase a wider range of foodstuffs.

loan.name: Sokheng

texts.en: Mr. Sokheng K. lives in Chek village in Kandal Province. He is a fisherman. His wife, Mrs. Sok Sokkim, is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil which has a bad effect on her crop. In order to deal with this problem, Mr. Sokheng K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support his wifeâ€™s field, and he will use the rest of money to buy rice seeds for the field. He hopes to increase income and improve his living conditions with this loan. He is 27 years old and the father of three children, who all stay at home.

loan.use: To buy fertilizers to support his wifeâ€™s field and to buy rice seeds.

loan.name: Pham Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Pham Thi X. lives in Hung Yen commune, Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. She is 31 years old and she has three children. She has been a member of TYM since 2002. Now her main income is from pigs and growing rice. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 10 million VND ($600 US) to buy more pigs and repair breeding facilities.

loan.use: To buy more pigs and repair breeding facilities.

loan.name: Lola

texts.en: Lola S. is 37 years old, married, and has three children who she supports by selling fabrics for sewing traditional clothes. Having worked in this business for almost ten years, Lola has good taste and is trusted by her clients to choose various textiles for many different kinds of occasions. She has also attracted a wide range of customers by offering fabrics at prices that appeal to all levels of the population. Lola's commercial success recently allowed her to open a second store in another market, and her overall income is now enough to send her son to university. In order to further develop her business, Lola is requesting a loan of $1000, which she will use to purchase an even wider array of fabrics for resale.

loan.use: To purchase more textiles for sewing traditional clothes.

loan.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 38 year old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their five children. Ahmad has been a barber for 20 years. He is known for his good service. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new seats for his salon. When he first started his business, he faced some difficulties because of the high number of barber shops around, but with time, he learnt how to make his shop attractive. He excels in his work and has very competitive prices. His future plan is to open a feminine hairdresser shop.

loan.use: Ahmad needs the loan to purchase new seats for his shop

loan.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi T. is 35 years old. She has been in TYM since 1998. For the first loan, she borrowed and invested in raising pigs. Now she owns a grocery shop, and this is her familyâ€™s main business. With an income of about 3 million VND ($175 US) per month, her familyâ€™s life is getting more and more stable. For the next loan, she wants to borrow 10 million VND ($600 US) to invest in her grocery shop.

loan.use: To invest in her grocery shop.

loan.name: Nouv

texts.en:
Mrs. Nouv E. is 57 years old and is a widow who has six children, two of whom are married and the other four live at home and help with house work. Nouv is a rice farmer, who started this in 1979. One of her sons, Mr. Kimseang Kang, 29, is a farmer who grows vegetables for income.

Nouv is facing a difficulty with a lack of farming equipment. Due to this obstacle, she decided to seE. a loan of 2,000,000 riel ($500) to buy a cow and buffalo to use for making her work easy. (Mrs. Nouv and her son are pictured).

loan.use: To buy a cow and buffalo

loan.name: Chhan

texts.en: Mrs. Chhan S. is a 49-year-old widow and she now lives in Lvea Sor Kandal village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land for cultivating rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces a problem because her field has infertile soil which makes her crop decline. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field. She would use the rest of the loan to buy rice seeds and fuel. She has four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the others are construction workers.

loan.use: To buy fertilizers, rice seeds and fuel.

loan.name: Met

texts.en:
Mr. Met S. is a 31-year-old fisherman, who relies on fishing in Tunle Sap Lake. He started in 2000, earning approximately $3 a day. His wife, Mrs. Sass Meut, 24, is a fish seller who sells fish from her husbandâ€™s work. They live in area of Loloksar Commune, Pursat Province.

Met needs to enlarge his business and he would like to request $150 to purchase a fishing boat and to buy more nets and traps.

loan.use: To purchase a fishing boat, nets and traps

loan.name: On

texts.en: Mr. On M. is a motorbike driver and he now lives in Lvea Sor Kraum village in Kandal Province. His wife, Mrs. Poeuv Sambath, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate mangoes. On this plantation, she faces a problem because her field has infertile soil which has a bad effect to her crop. Thus, Mr. On M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and he would use the rest of money to buy pesticides to kill insects to make his crop more productive. He is 44 years old and the father of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while anther one is a construction worker and the youngest one is too young to work or study. His wife is on the right of the picture.

loan.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and he would use the rest of money to buy pesticides to kill insects to make his crop more productive.

loan.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap M., 30, is widowed. Her occupation is as a rice farmer and she also raises pigs for income to support the familyâ€™s living. She has one daughter who studies in Grade 9, and they live in Loloksar Commune in Pursat Province.

Sopheap is applying for a $600 loan to purchase more piglets and more food for the pigs, and to buy rice for sale with the rest. The loan will help her to enlarge her business.

loan.use: To purchase more piglets

loan.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. N. lives in Bac Phu commune, Soc Son district, Ha Noi province. She is 58 years old and she has 4 children. She has been a member of TYM since 1995. Now her main income is from raising pigs and carpentry. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 10 million VND ($600 US) to buy pigs and materials to repair her house.

loan.use: To buy pigs and materials to repair her house.

loan.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
In the town of Plaridel, Misamis Occidental, lives a certain Mrs. Rosenda H. C., 39 years of age, married with 3 children. Her husband is a mere farmer tenant on the land which he inherited from his parents, because he has no choice, his parents were unable to send their children to school due to financial incapacity. Mrs. Rosenda C. realized that her husband's income is not sufficient for their daily needs.

In her own little way, she decided to make a backyard garden for their own consumption, but then their neighbors wanted to buy their vegetables. This being the case, she decided to expand her area, but unfortunately, she had no money to finance expansion.

She heard from a radio advertisement that Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative is offering a micro-finance program for marginalized people. She became a regular member April 11, 2000, received a loan amounting to PHP 5,000, and was able to expand her vegetable garden.

She is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000.00 for her 5,000 square meter garden. The loan is intended for purchasing fertilizers & pesticides for her vegetable garden.

Aside from financial assistance given by PMPC, Rosenda learned new technologies for vegetable production & capability-building, including savings mobilization. In the future, she and her husband dream of sending their children to college and of acquiring a parcel of land for their own.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers & pesticides for her market garden

loan.name: Yang

texts.en: Mrs. Yang Y. is a villager in Chek village in Kandal Province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Sok Sek, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, he faces some problems because his field is infertile, and he does not have rice seeds to cultivate. In order to deal with these problems, Mrs. Yang Y. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and she would use the rest of money to hire the laborers to work on the field. She is 35 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.

loan.use: Buy fertilizer and rice seeds and hire the laborers to work on the field.

loan.name: Phun

texts.en: Ms. Phun T., 50, is single and lives with her sister, Ms. Ly T., 38, who is a silk weaver. The family lives in a small village near the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phun has been a silk weaver since 2002 and has been selling silk fabric for three years. She buys the finished products from weavers in her village for resale at Oreu Sey market in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk fabric for resale.

loan.use: To purchase silk fabric for resale

loan.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita P. has been an active member of Paglaum-MPC for almost four years and is one of the pioneering members of Paglaum Development Program for Landless People. She has been living with her common-law husband Mr. David Quicoy for almost 10 years with her five children. She has a salted anchovies business - commonly known as "GINAMOS" - which has provided them with their daily needs. She's considered to be the bread winner of the family since her husband has no income. They also have a garden near their house which provides a good harvest and helps support the family with their daily expenses. Mrs. Pastarano hopes to purchase a decent house one day and fulfill her dreams of sending her children to school in the future.
She has a successfully paid back nine loans from PMPC and regularly contributes to her savings while building capital with PMPC. She's now planning to apply for her 10th loan in the amount of PHP 20,000 to purchase more "Ginamos" and fertilizer for her garden. Mrs. Rosita P. is considered to be a Member in Good Standing of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and has passed the credit evaluation for the approval of PHP 20,000.

loan.use: Purchase salted anchovies ( Ginamos) for sale and fertilizer for her garden

loan.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. C. lives in Bac Phu commune, Soc Son district, Ha Noi province. She is 37 years old and she has 4 children. She has been a member of TYM since 2001. Now her main income is from raising pigs and her husband's salary. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 10 million VND ($600 US) to invest in raising pigs.

loan.use: To invest in raising pigs.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To repair her house

loan.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap K. is a 29-year-old who has three children, all of whom still young, and they live in Ptasrong Commune, Pursat Province. Her husband, Mr. Saov Shon, is 28 years old. They are both local farmers who grow rice and vegetables for revenue to buy food for their kids to eat. Pheap requests a loan of 1,500,000 riel ($375) to purchase a buffalo for plowing their farmland for their rice crop yield. She hopes that a loan will help her to increase rice production higher than previous years. (Mrs. Pheap was not available, so her husband is pictured instead).

loan.use: To purchase a buffalo

loan.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi C. is 51 years old. She has 3 children. They are workers. In 2001 she joined TYM and borrowed 2 million VND ($120 US) and invested in raising farm animals, but now her main income is from selling clothes and her sonâ€™s salary. With an income of about 3 million VND ($175 US) per month, her familyâ€™s life is getting more and more stable. This time she wants to borrow 15 million VND ($900 US) to invest in her business and raising farm animals.

loan.use: To invest in her clothes-selling business and farm animals.

loan.name: Shodigul

texts.en:
Shodigul S. lives in the Huroson District. She is 49 years old. Her family is very large; she is married and has eight children. For the past seven years she has been raising livestock. She finishes - buys, fattens, and resells - cattle. Now she wants to increase the number of animals by buying a pure-bred bull calf. To do that she decided to take out an 18-month loan. This will improve her business and help her to further develop it.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of a pure-bred calf

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her children to use to go to work.

loan.name: Tugmahol

texts.en:
Tugmahol D. lives in the Huroson District. She is 53 years old, married, and has six children. She and her older sons raise livestock. For the past 8 years they have been buying bull calves to sell after a period of feeding. The business brings a fairly good income, but they would like to increase sales by buying another calf, and will need a loan to do so. The loan will be repaid over 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of complete feed and hay

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Safy

texts.fr: AgÃ©e de 31ans Safy est une femme mariÃ©e et mere de famille.Pour sirvenir Ã ses besoins ,elle vend des lÃ©gumes au coin du quartier .Chaque jour depuis 2 ans les femmes du quartier qui ne peuvent pas aller au marchÃ© achettent les legumes chez safy .Les recettes tirÃ©es de la vente des lÃ©gumes lui permettent de contribuer aux charges du menage.Avec le pretsollicitÃ©, elle compte renforcer son commerce.
texts.en:
Safy is a 31-year-old married mother with a family. To meet her needs, she sells vegetables on a corner in the neighborhood. Each day for two years, the neighborhood women unable to go to the market buy vegetables at Safy's place. The receipts derived from selling vegetables enable her to cover household expenses. With this loan being requested, she intends to boost her commerce.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Working capital

loan.name: Nizama

texts.en:
Nizama was born in 1971 and she lives in MeÄ‡ave, a village in Bosnia. She is married and has four children. Her husband works as an electrician, and Nizama grows vegetables and raises sheep and 2 cows. Nizama requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women, International, to purchase feed for her cows and sheep to survive the winter.

This loan is guaranteed by Zahida OsmanoviÄ‡.

loan.use: To purchase feed for her cows and sheep

loan.name: Zumra

texts.en:
Zumra was born in 1968 and she lives in a suburb of Bratonac in Bosnia. She is a widow with two young children, both of whom attend school. While she receives some income from her late husband`s pension, she largely supports her family by growing vegetables in a field and in a greenhouse. She sells the vegetables to her neighbors, and also at the local market.

Zumra requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women, International to purchase seeds and farming equipment for her vegetable business. She hopes that the additional income she receives from growing more vegetables will help her to provide a better life for her children. At this point, she is simply meeting her family`s most basic needs.

This loan is guaranteed by Zuhrija OmeroviÄ‡.

loan.use: To purchase supplies for vegetable farming

loan.name: Hairinisso

texts.ru: Ð”ÑƒÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð° Ð¥Ð°Ð¹Ñ€Ð¸Ð½Ð¸ÑÑÐ¾- Ð¿Ñ€ÐµÐ´Ð¿Ñ€Ð¸Ð½Ð¸Ð¼Ð°Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒ. ÐŸÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ð»ÐµÑ‚ Ð·Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ð¼Ð°ÐµÑ‚ÑÑ Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð³Ð¾Ð²Ð»ÐµÐ¹ . Ð˜Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ð¼Ð°Ð³Ð°Ð·Ð¸Ð½ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð´ÑƒÐºÑ‚Ð¾Ð² Ð¿Ð¸Ñ‚Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 18 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Hairinisso D. is an entrepreneur. She has been in sales for five years. She has a store where she sells foods. The goods are brought in from the city of Dushanbe, bought from wholesale stores. She is married and has four children. In fact, she raises the children alone, since her husband left for Russia to find work. She decided to request a loan with the goal of buying and installing additional shelving. In addition, the remaining money will be used to increase sales volume. The loan will be repaid over 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase additional shelving and increase sales volume

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Albert has been living in Barangay Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela since he was born. The people in their community are bonded with unity and cooperation which is manifested through helping each other in times of crisis. Specifically, corn and rice are the primary agricultural products of the people because of the areaâ€™s rich agricultural lands. Albert is married and has two (2) healthy children for which he is very thankful for.
Albert is engaged in buying and selling of domestic animals like carabao (water buffalo), cow, pig, and goat. Using his motorcycle, he transported these animals to the nearby province and then sold them at relatively higher prices. The nature of his business requires additional working capital but he just requested Php 5,000 for a start. Such an amount is big enough to add up to his revolving capital. He works hard and strives to improve his business in order to achieve his goals in life. His ultimate goal is for his family to be freed from poverty.
He believes in the essence of strong family ties and dreams to provide a good education for his two children.

loan.use: additional working capital

loan.name: Zuhrija

texts.en:
Zuhrija was born in 1952 and she lives in a suburb of Bratonac in Bosnia. She is married, and she works with her retired husband to grow vegetables and raise cows and chickens. Zuhrija requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women, International, which she will use to buy poultry and a calf, to expand their business and generate additional income for her family. At this point she is earning just enough money to meet her basic needs.

This loan is guaranteed by Zumra BajriÄ‡.

loan.use: To buy chickens and a calf

loan.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
Sharifa I. lives in the Huroson District. She has been working in sales for 10 years. She sells children's clothing from her stall at one of the district markets, in the village of Uyali. Sharifa is married and has four children. She decided to request a loan in order to increase her sales volume. She wants to bring in seasonal goods. Her work allows her to buy clothing right in town, without leaving the center, which saves her traveling expenses. The loan will be repaid over 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida was born in 1960 and she lives in Ravnice, a village in Bosnia. Zahida is a widow and she has one child, who is still in school. She receives income from her late husband`s pension, but she also raises chickens to keep busy. Zahida hopes to expand her chicken business and sell the meat in the local market. She requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women, International to buy chickens and feed for chickens.

This loan is guaranteed by Nizama MemiÄ‡.

loan.use: To buy chickens and food for chickens

loan.name: Kamu Kamu Women's Group A

texts.en: K. David is the chairperson of Kamu Kamu Womenâ€™s Group A in Kayunga. The group meets at his home where he has a wife and a number of children. David is a traditional healer, very smart at his job, using the spirit of his late father. People with all sorts of problems and sicknesses come to his place for the cure and people are not complaining. His drugs are well packaged so that they do no harm to his customers. David employs people to look for the herbs from the villages in Jinja, Kayunga, Iganga and as far as Kenya, as well as paying for the herbs. He is seeking a loan to be able to buy the herbs as well as pay for labor both for his business and on his farm.

loan.use: David needs to buy herbs and pay farm labor with the loan.

loan.name: Mirsada

texts.en:
Mirsada was born in 1950. She is a widow and lives alone in Breza, a village in Bosnia. Her husband died recently, so she has not yet begun receiving financial help from the government. Her only income comes from selling milk and milk products from her two cows, so she has been forced to ask her two adult children for financial help.

Mirsada requests a loan of 1,000KM from Women for Women, International to repair the barn for her cows, because it is currently damaged and unsafe.

loan.use: To repair her barn for her cows

loan.name: Jahongul

ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 18 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Jahongul B. lives in the Khuroson district. She and her family live in one of the district's remote villages. She has a store next to her house, where she sells foods as well as various commercial goods. Her store helps residents by providing constant access to these goods within the village. She wants to expand sales volume by bringing in a few types of clothing. This will attract new customers and also allow the village's residents to buy clothes right in their village. The repayment term is 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase sales. Purchase refrigerator.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Kodzo

texts.fr: Kodzo B. is a 30 year old married father. He lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from LomÃ©, the Togolese capital. To provide for his family, Koffi operates a taxi-moto business. With his motorcycle, Koffi picks up passengers along the road and drops them off at their destination. This service is always in demand in Wome, as there is no electricity in this village and people must often travel further than walking distance to take care of business. Koffi hopes to buy a new moto. With the profits he will earn from his business, Koffi can continue to send his children to school and provide for his wife and family.
texts.en:
Kodzo B. is a 30 year old married father. He lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from LomÃ©, the Togolese capital. To provide for his family, Koffi operates a taxi-moto business. With his motorcycle, Koffi picks up passengers along the road and drops them off at their destination. This service is always in demand in Wome, as there is no electricity in this village and people must often travel further than walking distance to take care of business. Koffi hopes to buy a new moto. With the profits he will earn from his business, Koffi can continue to send his children to school and provide for his wife and family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy a new moto

loan.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita lives in a typical village in Ballacong in the town of Ilagan, Isabela, where she is married to Rolando, a cook in a local restaurant. They have three children, two of whom are in high school while the third is an elementary student. Most of the residents here plant corn and rice as their primary source of living.
In order to help her husband, 12 years ago Angelita put up a community-based variety store, known in the Philippines as a â€œsari-sariâ€ store, where, from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. she sells commodities essential to the basic needs of the community such as bread, garlic, onion and canned goods.
Besides helping them sustain their daily needs, she hopes the business can also help her family to reach their dream, i.e., to send all their children to college. Teary eyed, Angelita said, â€œI work hard because I want to send my eldest daughter to college next year and then my other children thereafter. I want them to achieve what we failed to achieve.â€
She is therefore requesting a loan to increase her capital in order to purchase more stocks including sugar, milk, coffee and cooking ingredients. She believes that this will bring in more income to her store and little by little will help them realize their dreams.

loan.use: To purchase commodities such as sugar, milk, coffee, and cooking ingredients for her store.

loan.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom C., 26, is a grocery seller and has been making a living selling groceries including candy, eggs, seasoning and cakes since 2007. Her husband, Mr. Saody Chengh, is 27 years old and lives in Kdieydong Commune in Kompong Tom Province. He works outside his home as a construction worker and he currently earns approximately $2.50 per day. Mom has three children, two of whom are in school, while one is still young.

Mom hopes to run a new store for fried beef and boiled eggs to sell in front of her house; hence, she would like to apply for a $100 loan to make that possible.

loan.use: To run a new store for fried beef and boiled eggs

loan.name: Sangina

texts.en:
Sangina B. lives in the Huroson District. She is married, has five children, and is a housewife. She has a plot of land where she raises livestock, and sells milk as a small enterprise. After finding out about the availability of loans she contacted us about obtaining one. She decided to buy a young dairy cow whose milk she can sell at the market. This will provide income for her family. She will repay the loan over 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of a cow

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Kasuku Group

texts.en:
J. M., age 42, is married with five children (ages 22, 12, 9, 5 and 2). He sells second-hand clothes and has a fruit and vegetable business as well. He started his businesses six years ago. His business is open from 8am to 10pm daily and is able to make about $40 profit per month.
In the past, J. has taken out one loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more second-hand clothes for sale. He hopes for a new loan to start a barbershop for men. J. will share this loan with his loan group, Kasuku, which totals 16 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.
In the picture, J. is the first man standing on the right in the middle row .

loan.use: To start a barbershop for men

loan.name: Mahmuda

texts.en:
Mahmuda D. lives in the city of Kurgan-tube. She is 44 years old, married, and has three children. She has a secondary education. Mahmuda works in sales. She has a business that sells SIM cards and telephone cards. She decided to take out a loan to increase sales and make some repairs to the store. The loan will be repaid over six months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase sales

loan.name: New Africa Group

texts.en:
Hassan T., age 59, is married and has four children (ages 29, 25, 22, and 15). He has been selling empty bottles for 3 years now. He works from 8am to 5pm daily, and he makes about $292 per month.
He hopes to get a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his capital so that he can buy more bottles to sell. Hassan will share this loan with his group, New Africa, which has 21 members. These members hold each other accountable for repaying their loans.
In the picture, Hassan is the only man squatting in the front row.

loan.use: To buy bottles to sell

loan.name: Mavjuda

texts.ru: ÐÐ¾Ñ€Ð¼ÑƒÑ…Ð°Ð¼ÐµÐ´Ð¾Ð²Ð° ÐœÐ°Ð²Ð´Ð¶ÑƒÐ´Ð° Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ½Ð¸Ñ†Ð° Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° ÐšÑƒÑ€Ð³Ð°Ð½-Ð¢ÑŽÐ±Ðµ. Ð’Ð¾Ð·Ñ€Ð°ÑÑ‚ 28 Ð»ÐµÑ‚ . Ð˜Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ð´Ð²Ð¾Ð¸Ñ… Ð´ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹. Ð ÐµÑˆÐ¸Ð»Ð° Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾Ð±Ñ‹ Ð·Ð°Ð²ÐµÐ·Ñ‚Ð¸ ÑÐµÐ·Ð¾Ð½Ð½ÑƒÑŽ Ð¾Ð´ÐµÐ¶Ð´Ñƒ.Ð¢Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¸Ð²Ð¾Ð·Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð¸Ð· Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð”ÑƒÑˆÐ°Ð½Ð±Ðµ. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð¿Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 8 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Mavjuda N. lives in the city of Kurgan-Tube. She is 28 years old and has two children. For 15 years she has been working in sales. She has a stall in the Kurgan-Tube city market, where she sells children's clothing. She decided to use a loan to stock clothes for this season. The goods are brought in from Dushanbe. The loan will be repaid over 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase sales

loan.name: Salomey

texts.en:
Salomey N. is a 31-year-old married woman with two children, both of whom are in school. For the past 8 years, she has been a trader of clothes. Specifically, she runs her business by "hawking," which is door-to-door sales.

Salomey states that she is an overachiever and that her focus is to save enough money so that she can build a shop in which to display her goods. At present, however, she is seeking a loan to purchase additional used clothes in bulk to meet the demands of her customers.

She is a member of the community group known as the Angel Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on days when her group meets, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To meet her customers' demands by purchasing used clothes in bulk

payment.comment: retraction of repayment id 10235700

loan.name: Kamu Kamu Women's Group C

texts.en:
Harriet N. is a leader of Kamu kamu womenâ€™s group C in Kayunga. Harriet, 32, is married and has three children (ages 12, 7, and 4) who are all in school. She also cares for her sister by paying her school fees. Harriet has been in this lending group for one year and has various businesses. She has a retail shop that she has had for eight years, a salon that she has operated for a year. and, together with her husband, she has a bar. Harriet and her husband work together to see that all the businesses succeed. They have two dreams: that their children have the best possible education and that they own more land for farming. They are farmers now, though not on a very large scale. Harriet needs a loan to restock her shop, bar, and salon with goods.
This loan will be shared with her group members.

loan.use: To restock her shop, salon and bar with more goods.

loan.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther D. is a 51-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. For a living, she sells foodstuffs such as cassava, plantains, and maize in the local market of Ashaiman, where she lives. Having sold such foodstuffs for the past eight years, she has gained a lot of business experience and has developed a loyal customer base.
Esther notes that she is an overachiever, and that her goal is to save enough money so that she can provide her kids with a quality education and so that they can have a bright future. To that end, she is now seeking a loan to meet her customers' demands by purchasing an additional stock of cassava, plantains, maize, beans, etc.
She is a member of the community group known as the Angel Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on days when her group meets, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting. She would be grateful for any assistance provided.

loan.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional stocks of food (e.g., cassava, plantains, maize, and beans)

loan.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila A. A. is a 38-year-old married woman and the mother of three children, all of whom are currently in school. For a living, she trades in charcoal. Notably, charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in many traditional Ghanaian homes. Due to the success of her business, she was able to support her first child through senior high school. Sheila obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Tema, and she then resells such charcoal to her customers for a profit.

Unfortunately, her working capital (which was provided by her husband) is inadequate to enable her to purchase the large quantities of charcoal needed to meet her customersâ€™ demands. As a result, her sales and profit margins have been rather limited in recent months. Now, she is seeking a loan to purchase a bulk supply of charcoal in order to increase her charcoal inventory, and because she plans to start selling gari and maize to supplement her income (and thus needs capital to kickstart that line of business). She believes that the loan proceeds will enable her to increase her savings so that she can pay for her children's educational needs.

Sheila is a member of the community group known as The Voice Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell anything on days when her group meets, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To meet her customers' demands by expanding her charcoal inventory

loan.name: Avzalbi

texts.ru: Ð¡Ð°Ð¸Ð´Ð¾Ð²Ð° ÐÐ²Ð·Ð°Ð»Ð±Ð¸ Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ½Ð¸Ñ†Ð° Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° ÐšÑƒÑ€Ð³Ð°Ð½-Ñ‚ÑŽÐ±Ðµ. ÐŸÑ€Ð¾Ð¶Ð¸Ð²Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð²Ð¼ÐµÑÑ‚Ðµ ÑÐ¾ ÑÐ²Ð¾Ð¸Ð¼ ÑÑ‹Ð½Ð¾Ð¼. ÐŸÐ»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾Ð±Ñ‹ Ð·Ð°Ð²ÐµÐ·Ñ‚Ð¸ ÑÐµÐ·Ð¾Ð½Ð½Ñ‹Ð¹ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Avzalbi S. lives with her son in the town of Qurgan-Tube. She is divorced and is the sole provider for her family. She is engaged in a retail business at the Chinese market. She sells womenâ€™s fabrics and brings the goods from Dushanbe. She has a 7-year experience in this business. Avzalbi plans to obtain a 12-month loan in order to acquire seasonal goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To acquire seasonal goods

loan.name: Perpetual

texts.en:
Perpetual is a 46-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are currently in school. She loves selling goods, the business through which she obtains her source of livelihood. More specifically, for the past twenty years, she has been selling yams, peppers, and smoked and dried fish to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock of yams and peppers from farmers, and she buys her fish from fish mongers. By doing so, she avoids dealing with middlemen, who buy from the farmers and fish mongers and then resell to her at higher prices.

She is now seeking a loan to buy yams, peppers, and assorted fish in bulk to better serve her customers. In turn, she hopes to use some of her profits to support her kids in school.

Perpetual is a member of a community group known as The Voice Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any of her goods on days when her group meets, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To expand her inventory and to avoid middlemen by purchasing yams, peppers, and fish directly from farmers and fish mongers

loan.name: Muhayo

texts.ru: Ð¯ÐºÑƒÐ±Ð¾Ð²Ð° ÐœÑƒÑ…Ð°Ð¹Ðµ Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ½Ð¸Ñ†Ð° Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° ÐšÑƒÑ€Ð³Ð°Ð½-Ñ‚ÑŽÐ±Ðµ. Ð Ð°Ð·Ð²ÐµÐ´ÐµÐ½Ð° Ð¸ Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ð¾Ð´Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ñ€ÐµÐ±ÐµÐ½ÐºÐ°. Ð–Ð¸Ð²ÑƒÑ‚ Ð²Ð´Ð²Ð¾ÐµÐ¼. Ð¡ÐºÑƒÐ¿Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€ Ð½Ð° Ð¾Ð¿Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð¾Ð¼ Ñ€Ñ‹Ð½ÐºÐµ. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð¿Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¸ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Muhayo Y. lives in the city of Kurgan-Tube. She is divorced and lives with her one child. She has a business selling children's clothing, and already has five years of experience. She decided to request a loan to purchase the new season's goods, which are brought from the city Dushanbe. She buys the goods wholesale. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of the season's clothing

loan.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort D. is a 39-year-old married woman and mother, but she also cares for two of her sisterâ€™s kids. Currently three of the kids are in school, while the other children have completed school. Comfort enjoys selling goods, and she takes great pride in her superb customer service. Indeed, for the past eight years, she has been selling beans and maize to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock of beans and maize from farmers; by doing so, she avoids dealing with middlemen, who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices.

She is currently seeking a loan to buy beans and maize in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. In turn, she hopes to use some of her profits to support her children in school.

Comfort is a member of a community group known as the Voice Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on days when her group meets, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To expand her inventory and to avoid dealing with middlemen by purchasing beans and maize in bulk directly from farmers

loan.name: Tahmina

texts.en: Tahmina was born in 1963 and lives in Khachmaz town, Azerbaijan. She has run her own shop for the last three years. She is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy goods she needs to improve her small business.

loan.use: to buy additional goods for her small shop

loan.name: Abdumanon

texts.en: A. Abdumanon is 52 years old and was born in Isfara, Tajikistan. He is a father of two children, and his main work consists of breeding cattle. This very remunerative activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. A very ambitious man, he would like to buy a greater number of cattle and build a barn to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, he is asking for a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750 USD) for the realization of this project. He promises to repay the loan in 9 months. When his dream is carried out, he will be able to have a greater source of revenue for his growing family. With your help this will be possible.

loan.use: Purchase cattle and build a barn

loan.name: Gulnora

texts.en: Gulnora A. has worked with her husband for 15 years raising and reselling livestock in their village. They purchase calves in neighboring towns, feed them and eventually sell them to local butcher shops when the cows are mature. This is a job that Gulnora does with great care, because it provides her with satisfaction and allows her family to live a decent life. Most importantly, raising healthy animals allows her children to study in school. Gulnora currently hopes that she might be able to develop her family's business by purchasing even more calves next season. This would allow her to secure her children's education and professional careers. Therefore, Gulnora is requesting a loan of $900.

loan.use: To purchase more cattle for resale.

loan.name: Kosim

texts.ru: Ð¢ÑƒÑ€ÑÑƒÐ½Ð¾Ð² ÐšÐ¾ÑÐ¸Ð¼ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð¶Ð¸Ð²Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ðµ Ð¥ÑƒÑ€Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð½. Ð£Ð¶Ðµ 10 Ð»ÐµÑ‚ Ð·Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ð¼Ð°ÐµÑ‚ÑÑ Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð³Ð¾Ð²Ð»ÐµÐ¹ Ñ‚ÐºÐ°Ð½ÑÐ¼Ð¸. Ð­Ñ‚Ð¾ Ð´Ð°ÑÑ‚ Ð²Ð¾Ð·Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶Ð½Ð¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð²Ð¸Ð²Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð±Ð¸Ð·Ð½ÐµÑ Ð¸ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð´Ð¾Ñ…Ð¾Ð´Ñ‹ , Ð½ÐµÐ¾Ð±Ñ…Ð¾Ð´Ð¸Ð¼Ñ‹Ðµ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ð¾Ð±ÐµÑÐ¿ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ ÐµÐ³Ð¾ ÑÐµÐ¼ÑŒÐ¸.
texts.en:
Kosim T. lives in the Khuroson District. He has been working in the fabric sales business for 10 years already. He sells his goods at the Fakhrobod market of the Khuroson District. He is 46 years old, married, and has five children. To increase sales he decided to take out a 12 month loan. This will allow him to expand his business and increase profits, which he needs to do to support his family.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Wilhelmina

texts.en:
Wilhelmina A. started up her local restaurant twenty years ago in Ashaiman, where she resides. Since then, she has become one of the most popular food vendors in her neighborhood. She is now 56 years old, and she is married with three children, all of whom are currently in school. She serves a wide variety of local dishes such as fufu, rice balls, banku, and ampesi, among others. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantains, and it is eaten with soup. Meanwhile, banku is prepared from milled maize grains, and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. And, ampesi is a boiled plantain or yam, and it is taken with any stew.

She is now seeking a loan to buy more raw materials, including bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantains, meats, fish, vegetables, and firewood. Moreover, Wilhelmina hopes to use part of the loan proceeds to finance her childrenâ€™s education.

She is a member of the community group known as the Voice Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. Wilhelmina notes that her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional ingredients and materials (e.g., maize, cassava, plantains, meats, fish, vegetables, and firewood)

loan.name: Saidali

texts.ru: Ð‘Ð¾Ð±Ð¸ÐµÐ² Ð¡Ð°Ð¹Ð´Ð°Ð»Ð¸ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð¶Ð¸Ð²Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ðµ Ð¥ÑƒÑ€Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð½. Ð’Ð¾Ð·Ñ€Ð°ÑÑ‚ 34 Ð³Ð¾Ð´Ð°. Ð–ÐµÐ½Ð°Ñ‚ , Ð½Ð¾ Ð´ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹ Ð½Ðµ Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Saidali B. lives in the Khuroson regions. He is 34 years old, is married, but does not have children. Saidali owns a food store. He has been in this business for 15 years. He would like to expand his business by investing additional financial resources. This is only possible if he takes out a loan. After taking out a loan Saidali will purchase new products for sale. He can pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase inventory

loan.name: Gulchehra

texts.en: Gulchehra K. is 55 years old, married, and the mother of three grown children. About 36 years ago, she started a small business with the support of her husband, who still works as a farmer, to increase her family's income. Today, Gulchera's grocery store is well known in her community and has a stable base of customers who respect her business practices. Gulchera believes that her store's prestige and profitability could both be improved by offering a wider variety of foodstuffs and other products that will attract even more customers. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $1050 to purchase these products.

loan.use: To purchase a greater variety of groceries for resale.

loan.name: Paul Johnson

texts.en:
Paul Johnson T., a 33-year-old newly wed and father to a 10-year-old boy, is engaged in a food vending activity as a money-making venture. He is from Loon, Bohol but has spent his adolescence in Mindanao until he married. Later on, he decided to go back to his hometown to land inherited from his parents.
On that land, he built a small â€˜nipaâ€™ hut for his family and lived a simple life. As a neophyte in marriage, he began to worry about how he could sustain his family, considering he has no definite source of income. To help remedy the situation, he joined CEV and got into his business.
He chooses to sell food in the streets for it only requires minimal capital. He started his food vending business almost a year ago. His wife cooks the food while he sells it to his neighbors. With the income he gets from the daily vending, he is able to sustain his family.
With the aim of expanding his business, attracting more customers, and having a better place to display all the food items, he wants to build a food stall in front of his house. That is why he has requested, for the first time, a loan amounting to P 3,000.00. He hopes that in this way, he can guarantee a better future for his family.

loan.use: building a foodstall where he can display his food for sale

loan.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is 48 years old and the married mother of four children. Her children are currently in school. Beatrice sells frozen foods in the local market to support her family. She says demand for fish is high but she does not have the capital requirement to meet such demands. She wants to use the loan to purchase more cartons of frozen foods to enable her to raise enough income to support her children's education. She is a member of the borrowing group called Angels. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, mutton, etc.

loan.name: Sikyoomu Women's Group

texts.en:
Harriet N. is the chairperson of the Sikyoomu womenâ€™s group in Katosi, Lugazi. She is 38 years old and divorced. She lives with her three children in Katosi. Harriet has a retail shop that she has owned for 10 years. When she restocks her shop, she buys from the wholesale shops in Katosi so she does not have to incur more transportation costs. However, when itâ€™s time to pay school fees, she is short on money to restock her business. She is the only bread winner at home, so she is grateful for the loans that allow her to restock her shop to a state where she can make enough profit to provide for herself and her children as well as to repay her loans on time.
She will share this loan with her group members.

loan.use: To buy more goods for her shop.

loan.name: Shoira

texts.en: Shoira N. is a hard-working and energetic mother who has been selling clothes of various colors, styles, and sizes at in her local market for over five years. Her high quality workmanship and good taste have attracted many new customers to her business, and now Shoira is hoping that her business may continue to grow. In order to achieve this goal, she is requesting a loan of $800, which will be used to purchase a wider variety of clothes for resale.

loan.use: To purchase a greater quantity of clothes for resale.

loan.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret P. is a 33-year-old married woman with three children. She lives with her family in Tema-Ashaiman in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. For the past six years, she has run a clothing shop, where she sells ladies' and children's wears, such as blouses, skirts, lingerie, and underwear.

Unfortunately, she is constrained by her limited working capital in running the business. As such, she is seeking a loan to inject more working capital into the business in order to expand and improve her business. More specifically, she believes that the loan proceeds will enable her to purchase high-quality inventory in bulk.

She is a member of the group known as the Angel. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on group meeting days, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting. She is very grateful for your assistance.

loan.use: To expand and upgrade her inventory by purchasing high-quality items (e.g., lingerie and underwear) in bulk

payment.comment: retraction of repayment id 10235719
retraction of repayment id 10235720
retraction of repayment id 10235721

loan.name: Suun

ÐžÑ‚ÐºÐ¾Ñ€Ð¼Ð¸Ð² ÐµÐ³Ð¾ Ð¾Ð½ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð·Ð°Ñ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð´ÐµÐ½ÑŒÐ³Ð¸. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Suun B. lives in the Bakhsh district. He is 39 years old, married, and has four children. He has a secondary education. Suun has raised and sold cattle his whole life. He finishes bull calves for sale to butchers for meat. His work always results in high quality meat. To increase his number of cattle he decided to take out a loan and buy one more calf. Raising it will earn him money. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of a calf

loan.name: Kamu Kamu Group B

texts.en:
Fred M. is a hard working and ambitious young man of 31 years of age He is the leader of the Kamu kamu womenâ€™s group B in Kayunga. Fred has had a wholesale food shop in the Bukeeka township of Kayunga for 10 years. He is married and has three children (ages 10, 5, and 3) who are all in school. He has been in this lending group for five years now. As a result of his work with and involvement in this lending group, Fred has bought four boda bodas (bicycle taxis) and with this loan, he plans to buy another boda boda and other goods for his shop. Fredâ€™s wife is a farmer who manages their farms with hired helpers. Fred and his wife have a dream of one day buying a commercial car.
He will share this loan with his group members.

loan.use: To buy more goods for shop and a boda boda

loan.name: Mary Jeane

texts.en:
â€œThe most challenging part of being a wife and mother is: how are you going to raise all of your 5 children well with your husband earning only P 7,000.00 per month--not enough to cover your whole family's basic needs," says Mary Jeane S., 33 years old, from Loon, Bohol who sincerely shares her experiences as a married person.

Mary Jeane went into a small sing-along business situated beside her nipa hut to increase her family's income and earn an additional P1, 000 per month. However, she cannot maximize her income due to a lack of facilities. Her chairs and tables are made of coconut lumber and slightly rotten, making the customers feel discomfort every time they visit the place.

She is requesting a loan of P 5,000.00 to purchase these items. In addition, she wants to invest in some other business such as a small grocery store, so 40% of the loan money will be used to purchase grocery items for her store. She hopes that if she manages to do all this, raising her children may not be as difficult as she previously said.

loan.use: To purchase new chairs and tables for her sing-along business

loan.name: Mahfuza

texts.en: Mahfuza R. is married and has one son. Her husband works as a laborer and earns a relatively meagre income. In order to contribute to her family's overall income, Mahfuza started a small business four years ago selling electrical goods and various housewares. Since then she has been increasing the range of goods in her shop, and is now requesting a loan of $750, which she will use to do some minor remodeling to her business and more importantly purchase a wide variety of products for resale.

loan.use: To purchase a wider range of electrical goods for resale.

loan.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice A. is 54 years old. She is a wife and the mother of five children. Currently two of her kids are in school. She is a retailer of charcoal, maize and gari at her local community. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in most traditional Ghanaian homes. Beatrice purchases her supply of charcoal from the villages and retails it to her customers, as she also does with the bags of maize and gari.

She has supported two of her children to finish school with the income from her business. With the loan, she wants to buy more charcoal, and bags of maize and gari to serve her customers. She hopes the loan would enable her to save more to support her other two children to finish school. She would be very grateful for that support.

Beatrice belongs to the trust group called Angels. Members of this group agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To purchase more charcoal, maize and gari.

loan.name: Snat

Ð”Ð»Ñ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð¾Ð½ Ð¾Ð±Ñ€Ð°Ñ‚Ð¸Ð»ÑÑ Ðº Ð½Ð°Ð¼ Ð·Ð° Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸ÐµÐ¼ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚Ð°. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Snat B. lives in the Bakhsh District. He is 23 years old. He has been raising livestock for five years. He has a few head of cattle, and they must have high quality feed. Because of that he decided to buy hay and pre-mixed complete feed. Having a stock of that feed will result in well finished animals. To do this he contacted us about receiving a loan. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Complete feed supply

loan.name: Golib

texts.en: Golib U. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Spitamen in Tajikistan. He supports his family by raising cattle, which he sells to a butcher shop in the local market after fattening them to a desirable size over the course of eight or nine months. Golib recently realized that his business has the potential for significant growth, and has decided to purchase two more calves each season that usual. In order to achieve this goal, which will allow him to earn more profit and better support his family, Golib is requesting a loan of $750.

loan.use: To purchase more cattle for resale.

loan.name: Sayyara

texts.en: Sayyara is a widow who has three children. She lives with her family in the village of Garadag-Budug, which is located in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Six years ago she started her own cattle-breeding business. Now she is applying for a loan to buy baling presses.

loan.use: to buy baling presses for a cattle-raising business

loan.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort O. is a 43-year-old married woman, and she is the mother of two kids. One of her children is in school, while the other child has completed school. Comfort is a distributor and a supplier of ice cream products (e.g., yogurt and ice cream) at a very busy market in Tema, where she lives. She accepts deliveries from dairy manufacturers, and she then supplies retailers with such products. Comfort has been in this business for the past 2 years, during which time she has gained invaluable business experience.

She is now requesting a loan to purchase greater supplies of ice cream products as well as deep freezers so that she can better stock her products. In turn, she believes the loan proceeds will enable her to pay for her child's school expenses.

Comfort belongs to the community group known as the Morning Star Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on group meeting days, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting. She is very grateful for your assistance.

loan.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional dairy products and to improve her business by purchasing deep freezers

loan.name: Mukadam

texts.en: Mukadam A. is married and lives with her husband and three children. While her husband works as a labourer in their village, Mukadam manages the shop she opened three years ago selling kitchen supplies. Having started this business to help contribute to her family's income and standard of living, Mukadam now sees the potential for a significant expansion by purchasing additional inventories of kitchen supplies. This will increase her profits and allow her to start saving money for her children's education. Therefore, Mukadem is requesting a loan of $750, which she will use to increase her shop's inventory.

loan.use: To purchase a greater quantity of kitchen supplies for resale.

loan.name: Nozir

texts.en: Nozir I. is 45 years old, married, and has four children who he supports by raising and selling sheep. By purchasing sheep in the central market and caring for them, Nozir is able to resell them at much higher prices. He learned this trade from his father and is recognized in his village as being an expert with livestock. Despite the fact that Nozir rises at five o'clock every morning to care of his animals, and continues working until it is dark again at night, his family is still poor and struggles to pay for basic necessities. In order to improve their standard of living, he is requesting a loan of $750 to purchase more sheep.

loan.use: To purchase more sheep for resale.

loan.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is a 38-year-old married woman with three children, all of whom are currently in school. She is a busy petty trader who has been selling maize grain, plantains, cassava, and other foodstuffs on a table at the local market for the past eight years. More specifically, she has been trading in the market of Tema in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana, where she resides with her family.

Unfortunately, she does not have sufficient working capital to properly run her business, thereby retarding the business' progress. As such, she is seeking a loan to inject more working capital into the business so that she can purchase additional inventory to revive the business. In turn, she believes that the loan proceeds will enable her to increase her savings in order to support her kids in school.

Grace belongs to the group known as the Morning Star Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on group meeting days, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting. She is very grateful for your assistance.

loan.use: To revive her business by expanding her inventory (e.g., stocks of cassava, fresh tomatoes, onions, beans, maize, and dried fish)

loan.name: Rahmatullo

texts.ru: Ð˜Ð¼Ð¾Ð¼Ð¾Ð² Ð Ð°Ñ…Ð¼Ð°Ñ‚ÑƒÐ»Ð»Ð¾ Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° ÐšÐ£Ñ€Ð³Ð°Ð½-Ñ‚ÑŽÐ±Ðµ. Ð–ÐµÐ½Ð°Ñ‚ Ð¸ Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ñ‚Ñ€Ð¾Ð¸Ñ… Ð´ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹. Ð¡ÐµÐ¹Ñ‡Ð°Ñ Ñ…Ð¾Ñ‡ÐµÑ‚ ÐµÑ‰Ðµ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€Ð¾Ð¾Ð±Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ñ‚ , Ð¿ÑƒÑ‚ÐµÐ¼ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚Ð°. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Rahmatullo I. lives in Qurgan-Tube. He is married and has 3 children. He has worked in sales for 6 years now. Rahmatullo sells office supplies at the central market. His sales location is on a main path in the market. Sales are not bad and bring good profits. In addition, his prices are not high and as a result he has a lot of customers. Rahmatullo would like to increase his inventory by taking out a loan. He plans to pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase inventory

loan.name: Muharram

texts.en: Muharram R. is 49 years old, married, and has three children. As a dynamic and caring mother, Muharrram works hard as a market vendor to provide for her family. She sells many kinds of hair accessories for girls and women and earns enough profit to cover the expenses of schooling and university for her children. In order to guarantee that they have access to education, Muharram wants to wants to increase the variety of products in her store and bolster the inventory of these goods. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $750 to purchase these goods.

loan.use: To purchase a greater quantitiy of hair products for resale.

loan.name: Yazdonkul

texts.en: Yazdonkul Z. is 47 years old and married with three children. He has been breeding sheep since he was a young boy and enjoys working with animals on a daily basis. Yazdonkul recently realized that demand for his products has increased enough to justify the acquisition of several more livestock. In order to accommodate these sheep, his family's facilities and barn will have to be expanded and improved. Therefore, Yazdonkul is requesting a loan of $750, which will be used to purchase more sheep and materials for rebuilding his barn.

loan.use: To purchase more sheep and expand farm facilities.

loan.name: Adham

texts.en:
Adham is a 38-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Adham has a small restaurant where he sells falafel and â€œshawarmaâ€ (chicken) sandwiches. He has been in this business for 20 years. He requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to pay the school tuition fees for his children.

Adham has a good reputation and has a lot of clients. In the future, he plans to expand his business and maybe diversify his choice of food. This is the third cycle for Adham in a micro-credit field.

loan.use: Adham needs the loan to pay the school tuition fees for his children

loan.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence A. is a 32-year-old married woman with two children. To earn a living, she has been a trader for the past seven years; in particular, she sells used clothes in the local market of Tema. With income from her business, Florence is able to support all of her children in junior high school.

Her major business challenge over the years is her lack of funding, which prevents her from scaling up the business. She has a great deal of marketing experience, so she is very confident that she can improve the business with an injection of capital. As such, she is seeking a loan to enable her to achieve remarkable business progress. Specifically, she would use the loan proceeds to buy more bales of used clothes to meet her customers' demands. In turn, she hopes to save enough money to support her kids until they complete their schooling.

She belongs to the group known as the Morning Star Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loan.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional bales of used clothes.

loan.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 32-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife. Ahmad has been working in transportation for the last three years. He used to work as a taxi driver until a friend recommended that he buy a pick-up and start his transportation business. Now Ahmad works in public transportation and he also moves furniture and lumber. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a bigger truck. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

loan.use: Ahmad needs the loan to purchase a pick-up truck

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase grocery items, vegetables, and spices in bulk for re-sale

loan.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana S., from Surallah South Cotabato City, is the mother of seven and an entrepreneur who has always dreamed of a better life for her family. A CEV client for four years already, Feliciana used the loan she previously received from CEV to start her own rattan furniture business. Accommodating the schools, her friends and other people, she has been able to firmly establish her business and provide for all her familyâ€™s needs.

Feliciana is now requesting another loan in order to purchase furniture materials. In an interview she said that she wants to add more displays of sofas, dividers, and beds to her store so as to attract more customers and increase her sales volume. An improved income will allow her to send all of her children to college. â€œAs a mother, all I want for my children is for them to finish their studies and live a comfortable life,â€ she added.

loan.use: To purchase furniture materials

loan.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Mr G. est un chauffeur agÃ© de 43 ans mariÃ© et de famille qui fait de l'elevage de la volail sa seconde activitÃ© depuis trois ans il a construit chez lui un poulailet qui sert Ã l' Ã©levage des poulets de chairs.chaque matin avant d ' aller au travail il s 'occupe des poulets et la journÃ©e sa fill ainÃ©e prend le relais.Il sollicite un pret pour renforcer son activitÃ© .
texts.en:
Mr. G., age 43, is a chauffeur, married, and a father of a family. He has been raising poultry as his other work for three years. At his home, he has built a chicken coop for raising fryer chickens. Each morning before going to work, he takes care of the hens. And during the daytime, his eldest daughter take over for him. He is requesting a loan to bolster his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Working capital

loan.name: Marline

texts.en:
Marline G., dried fish dealer and 32-year-old entrepreneur whose husband is a tricycle driver from Surallah, South Cotabato, never stops doing business to be able to send their 2 children to school.
In 2001, she got herself started up in a fish-vending business and humbly started out with only Php 2, 000 capital. From the profit she earned, she was able to support all her family needs.
She is a top-performing CEV client who needs the additional capital of Php 21,000 for her dried fish business. She believes that through her CEV loan she will be able to add to her inventory of dried fish and make more sales. â€œI need to invest more to accommodate all my customers,â€ she says. â€œCompetition is really tough nowadays, so I need to do something to sustain my business for my family,â€ she added.

loan.use: To purchase all kinds of dried fish

loan.name: Morris 1- Getrude Group

texts.en:
Getrude N., a 40-year-old female Ugandan, is married with 3 children aged 18 to 8 years. On acquiring some snack-making skills from a friend, Getrude was supported by her husband to start the business of frying cookies, doughnuts, and crackers and selling them to schools, offices and shops in her locality.

Her five-year-old business is mostly affected by the persistent inflation rate in the country, which affects the prices of major ingredients required for her snacks. This makes it difficult for her to compete with those who purchase the ingredients in bulk who are therefor not so affected by the price rises. Getrude is using the loan to purchase enough cooking oil, wheat flour and sugar.

Besides being social and welcoming, she attracts her customers by ensuring that her working area is clean. She hopes to extend her services to catering for functions like conferences and weddings, and also help her husband in setting up their residence. On good days, Getrude makes a profit of 15,000 UGX. It is from these profits that she affords to pay for her semi-permanent stall at the rate of 50,000 UGX per month.

loan.use: Purchase enough cooking oil, wheat flour and sugar.

loan.name: Musigula-Victo Group

texts.en:
Due to the high inflation rate in the country that has infringed on profits, Victo M. finds it necessary to acquire a loan that will enable her purchase ingredients like sugar and wheat flour for her retail grocery shop in bulk before a further rise in prices, and also an extra sewing machine with some fabrics for her tailoring business. She has been running these businesses under one roof in a stall she rents in Bulwa zone.

She is 38 years old, married and the loving mother of six children aged 15 years to 5 months, of whom 5 are in school. When she tired of being a housewife 5 years ago, her husband and a driver with Lake Victoria environmental management, helped her raise capital for both businesses. She has hence kept her businesses going by providing excellent customer care to her clients and maintaining good hygiene at her stall.

This is Victoâ€™s 2nd loan with BRAC Uganda and she hopes it will help her business grow, thereby increasing profits. With such financial progress, she looks forward to supporting her husband in raising funds for the purchase a plot of land and construction of their residence. She also dreams of extending training services in tailoring and also providing clothing for functions like weddings, traditional marriages and graduations.

loan.use: Purchase ingredients like sugar and wheat flour for her retail grocery shop

loan.name: Fatou Ndiaye

texts.fr: Fatou Ndiaye S., 45 ans, mariÃ©e, 07 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de CESIRI depuis 1 an et demi. Elle veut renforcer son commerce dâ€™huile de palme, dâ€™arachide, lÃ©gumes et de tissu teintÃ© quâ€™elle achÃ¨te au Mali. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer au paiement de la facture dâ€™Ã©lectricitÃ© de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prÃªt qui sera remboursÃ© au bout de six mois en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance.
texts.en:
Fatou Ndiaye S., age 45, is married and has seven children in her care. She has been a member of the village loan group CESIRI for a year and a half. She wants to bolster her business in palm oil, peanuts, vegetables, and dyed cloth, which she buys in Mali. Her income enables her to help pay the family electricity bill. She is applying for a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy palm oil, peantus, and dyed fabrics

loan.name: Akil

texts.en: Akil is a 31-year-old married man with two young children, living in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon. A car mechanic for several years, he opened his own workshop in 2000. He took his first micro-loan to buy tools for his shop and introduce additional services. As his business is expanding, Akil wants to borrow US$1,200 to ameliorate the technology he possesses by buying a lifting apparatus for trucks.

loan.use: To buy new machinery

loan.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou S., 54 ans est mariÃ©e et a la charge de 04 enfants quâ€™on lui a confiÃ©s. Elle est membre du banc villageois de CESIRI depuis 1 an et demi. Fatou est propriÃ©taire dâ€™un atelier de couture et elle vend des cÃ©rÃ©ales aussi. Elle veut un prÃªt pour acheter des tissus (bazin et percale), des fournitures, une machine Ã coudre ordinaire, des cÃ©rÃ©ales et des emballages pour renforcer ses activitÃ©s de couture et de commerce. Le prÃªt quâ€™elle sollicite sera remboursÃ© au bout de six mois en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance.
texts.en:
Fatou S. is 54 years old, married, and has 4 children to support, who were entrusted to her. She's been a member of the CESIRI village bank for one and a half year. Fatou owns a sewing workshop and she also sells cereals. She's seeking a loan to buy fabrics (Bazin and percale), supplies, an ordinary sewing machine, cereals, and packagings, in order to bolster her business. The loan she's seeking will be repaid after six months, in one single installment.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy fabrics, one sewing machine, supplies and cereals

loan.name: Naji

texts.en: Naji is a 49-year-old man, married with three children, living in Burj Al Barajneh, a suburban area of Beirut. He started his internet cafe in his neighborhood in 2005 after noticing a lack of such services in the area. His internet cafe is a safe haven for local children. As technology becomes obsolete very fast, Naji wants to borrow USD 1,200 in order to buy newer and more sophisticated computers.

loan.use: Buying computers for his internet cafe

loan.name: NdathÃ©

texts.fr: NdathÃ©, 45 ans, mariÃ©e, 10 enfants et 02 autres en charge est membre du banc villageois de CESIRI depuis 1 an et demi. Elle veut renforcer son commerce de tissu teintÃ© (Ganila, 1er choix et 2Ã¨me choix). Elle vend aussi des produits de beautÃ©. Ses revenus lui permettent dâ€™entretenir ses enfants et dâ€™Ã©quiper sa maison. Elle sollicite un prÃªt qui sera remboursÃ© au bout de six mois en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance.
texts.en:
NdathÃ©, age 45, is married and has ten children plus two others to look after. She has been a member of the village loan group CESIRI for a year and a half. She wants to bolster her business in dyed fabrics (Ganila, first choice and second choice). She also sells beauty products. Her income enables her to care for her children and to equip her house. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy dyed cloth

loan.name: Juan Alberto

texts.es:
El seÃ±or Juan Alberto D. se dedica a su negocio de pulperÃ­a el cual es atendido en su casa de habitaciÃ³n en el municipio de Telica de la bella ciudad de LeÃ³n. Este caballero se ha caracterizado por ser un buen esposo y un buen padre por la razÃ³n que siempre ha llevado el sustento a su hogar porque se ha dedicado arduamente a su negocio.
El motivo por el cual Ã©l ha acudido a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crÃ©dito que le permita la compra de granos bÃ¡sicos para comercializarlos en la pulperÃ­a. Es por esto que muy confiadamente espera que su crÃ©dito le sea otorgado y de esta forma salir adelante en su negocio de pulperÃ­a.
texts.en:
SeÃ±or Juan Alberto D. is dedicated to his store business which he attends in his house in the municipality of Telica of the beautiful city of LeÃ³n. This gentleman has been characterized as being a good husband and a good father for the reason that he has always made a living for his household because he has been dedicated arduously to his business.

The motive that has brought him to Ceprodel to request a loan is the purchase of basic grains to allow him to market them in the store. It is for this that he very confidently hopes that the loan will be offered to him and in this way he will do well in his store business.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy basic grains to sell in his store

loan.name: Oumy

texts.fr: Oumy N., 37 ans, veuve avec 04 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de CESIRI depuis 1 an et demi. Elle veut un prÃªt pour renforcer ses activitÃ©s de restauration et de commerce dâ€™effets vestimentaires, chaussures et pochettes Le prÃªt quâ€™elle sollicite sera remboursÃ© au bout de six mois en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance.
texts.en:
Oumy N., aged 37 and a widow with four children in her care, has been a member of the CESIRI Village Bank for 18 months. She wants a loan to strengthen her restaurant business as well as her business involving the sale of clothing, shoes and purses. The loan she is requesting will be repaid after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy supplies for her restaurant and shoes and purses for resale

loan.name: Sonko

texts.fr: Sonko SamakÃ© est mariÃ©e avec 07 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de CESIRI depuis 1 an et demi. Sonko veut acheter de lâ€™huile de palme, de la pÃ¢te dâ€™arachide, du poisson sÃ©chÃ©, des huÃ®tres et autres marchandises diverses pour renforcer le niveau de sa table au marchÃ© Elle sollicite un prÃªt qui sera remboursÃ© au bout de six mois en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance.
texts.en:
Sonko SamakÃ© is married with 7 children to care for. She has been a member of the village council CESIRI for a year and a half. Sonko wants to buy palm oil, peanut butter, dried fish, oysters, and other diverse goods to build up the level of her table at the market. She is seeking a loan which she will repay at the end of six months in one payment.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy palm oil, peanuts, dried fish and oysters

loan.name: MarÃ­a Antonia

texts.es:
La seÃ±ora MarÃ­a Antonia R. es originaria del municipio de Telica de la ciudad de LeÃ³n donde se dedica a atender su propia pulperÃ­a el cual la inaugurÃ³ desde hace 15 aÃ±os con pocos recursos econÃ³micos y realizando pocas ventas.
