Ð¡Ñ‚Ð°Ñ€ÑˆÐ¸Ðµ ÑÑ‹Ð½Ð¾Ð²ÑŒÑ ÑƒÐ¶Ðµ Ð²Ð·Ñ€Ð¾ÑÐ»Ñ‹Ðµ Ð¸ Ð¿Ð¾Ð¼Ð¾Ð³Ð°ÑŽÑ‚ Ð¼Ð°Ñ‚ÐµÑ€Ð¸ Ð² ÐµÐµ Ð´ÐµÐ»Ðµ.
texts.en:
M. Hamidova lives in the Bokhtar District. As a businesswoman, she has been in sales for 7 years. She sells fruits and vegetables at the district's food market. The goods she sells are essentials, so her business yields a profit. She decided to take out a loan to increase sales turnover, which will help increase business. She brings potatoes and onions in so that people can stock up for the winter. The loan will be repaid over 10 months. M. is married and has eight children. The eldest sons are already grown and help in their mother's business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Eleonora

texts.en:
Eleonora lives with her husband Franklin and their four children in the peaceful community of Ballacong in Ilagan, Isabela. For the past three years, Eleonora has sold second-hand RTW (Ready to Wear) clothes and apparel to the community.
Selling second hand or used clothing is most commonly known as â€œukay-ukayâ€ in the Philippines. Eleonora always buys the best clothes without damage so her customers will be satisfied with what they buy from her.
Because of the high demand for used clothing, Eleonora needs a loan of Php17, 000 to buy more clothing. She is also planning to use some of her loan to buy farm supplies such as fertilizer and pesticides for their corn field.
She hopes and prays that her business will continue to grow and become stable so they can send their children to school and have better standard of living.

loan.use: To buy used clothing

loan.name: Tem

texts.en: Mrs. Tem H. is a villager in Trapaing Tra Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a poultry breeder who raises ducks. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it and decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding. Her husband, Mr. San Phany, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. She is 56 years old and the mother of seven children. Three help their mother in the current business while two others are farmers. The remaining two children are laborers. Her husband is presented on the left of this photo.

loan.use: To buy more ducks for breeding.

loan.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia, 45, is thankful for the life that she has together with her husband and their four sons and one daughter. They might be financially unstable and still striving to provide for their childrenâ€™s education, but she knows that with perseverance and hard work they can still have a life much better than what they have right now.
Together with her husband Florante, she sells vegetables and spices in the public market of Ilagan, Isabela. They strive to be very industrious running their business because it is their only source of income. They want it to be sustainable and really grow so that they can provide for their familyâ€™s basic needs and send their children to school. She strongly believes that their business will pave the way to a better future.
Eufemia is requesting to borrow Php15,000. She plans to use the loan to buy more vegetables and spices. At present, Eufemia makes about PHP2,100 a week, which they use to pay for such things as food, education, and other basic needs.

loan.use: To buy vegetables and spices

loan.name: Zaripova

texts.ru: Ð—Ð°Ñ€Ð¸Ð¿Ð¾Ð²Ð° Ð“ÑƒÐ»Ð¸ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð½ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð¶Ð¸Ð²Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ðµ Ð’Ð°Ñ…Ñˆ. Ð•Ð¹ 30 Ð»ÐµÑ‚ Ð¸ Ð¾Ð½Ð° Ð½Ðµ Ð·Ð°Ð¼ÑƒÐ¶ÐµÐ¼. Ð”ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹ Ð½Ðµ Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
G. Zaripova lives in the Vakhsh District. She is 30 years old, unmarried, and has no children. She has completed university, where she was trained as a doctor. She does not work in her specialty though, but in sales. For the past five years she has been selling fruits and vegetables. She rents a place, but in order to work out a long rent term without any conflicts she needs to take out a loan for the rent payment. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Rent payment

loan.name: Sokhim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhim B. was born in 1968 and now lives in Trapaing Sla Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a 40-year-old widow with three children. One child is a teacher who makes a small salary to support the household. Another one is employed in a garment factory and the third has emigrated to work in Malaysia.

Mrs. Sokhim B. is a farmer and owns a small piece of land used to cultivate rice to earn a living. Aside from working on her plantation, she is also a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to buy five more piglets for breeding. With the rest of the loan, she will buy food and medication for her animals.

loan.use: To buy five more piglets for breeding.

loan.name: Channa

texts.en: Mrs. Channa K. is a villager in Sromor Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a poultry breeder who breeds ducks. Since her ducks have delivered many ducklings, she does not have enough money to buy more duck food to support them so she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Seik Sam Ol, helps her in the current business. Mrs. Channa K. is 38 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school.

loan.use: To buy duck food.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To buy four more piglets for breeding.

loan.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline A. lives in a small village where farming is the major source of income. She is 50 years old and single so she lives with her immediate family.
Evangeline wants to help her nieces in their studies, so she has started a business selling personal care products such as perfume and lotion, as well as apparel for children such as slippers, shoes, and bags.
Her loan request of Php5, 000 will be used to purchase additional merchandise to expand her business. Through this, she expects that her sales and her income will increase. She hopes that her business will thrive so she can continue to help her nieces financially in providing them with a daily school allowance.

loan.use: To buy additional inventory

loan.name: Lelbi

texts.ru: ÐšÐ°Ð¼Ð¾Ð»Ð¾Ð²Ð° Ð›ÐµÐ»Ð±Ð¸ Ð±Ð¸Ð·Ð½ÐµÑÐ¼ÐµÐ½. Ð—Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ð¼Ð°ÐµÑ‚ÑÑ Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð³Ð¾Ð²Ð»ÐµÐ¹ ÑƒÐ¶Ðµ 9 Ð»ÐµÑ‚. Ð•Ð¹ 46 Ð»ÐµÑ‚ Ð¸ Ð¾Ð½Ð° Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ñ‡ÐµÑ‚Ð²ÐµÑ€Ñ‹Ñ… Ð´ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹. Ð”Ð»Ñ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ , Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾Ð±Ñ‹ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€Ð¾Ð¾Ð±Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ñ‚ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ñ‚Ñ‚ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð² Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð¼ÐµÑ€Ðµ 2000 ÑÐ¾Ð¼Ð¾Ð½Ð¸. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¸ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Lelbi K. is a businesswoman. She has worked in sales for 9 years already. She is 46 years old and has four children. She sells fruit in the Vakhsh District market. To increase sales she is requesting and 2000 ($600) somoni loan. It will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda, 44, who hails from Clarin, Misamis Occidental is married to Lauro N., who is a typical farmer. During the first year of their marriage, Melinda had a miscarriage which left her unable to have children anymore. She then just contented herself looking after the house and help her husband in his farming chores.To while away her time she decided to join PMPC and got deeply involved in its community activities. She was even able to organize a group of women in her village to develop their entrepreneurial capacities.
After undergoing a series of training conducted by PMPC on how to become an entrepreneur and manage household finances, she then renovated the frontage of her house and converted it into a small retail shop. She was able to do this using a start-up loan of PHP 2,000 from PMPC. Her little business gradually grew and after two years she was able to increase her working capital to PHP 20,000. She is now able to earn an income of her own and not depend so much on the meager income from the farm of her husband. While the couple is childless, Melinda has focused her attention on leading the group of women entrepreneurs she organized in her village and help them succeed in their ventures.
Records of PMPC would show that for 15 loan cycles, Melinda has no record of default, and she was able to maintain her Member In Good Standing status. Her husband also helps her business when he is not on the farm.
Her knowledge about how to handle customers properly helped her gain additional regular clients and increase the demand for her goods. Now she is applying for a loan worth PHP 20,000 for the purchase of additional stocks to further expand her retail shop.
The coupleâ€™s future plan is to increase their business assets so that they can build a concrete sari-sari store to protect their stocks. They also have plans to renovate their house, as it is only made of light materials.

loan.use: Purchase additional stocks for her retail shop

loan.name: Phally

texts.en: Mrs. Phally T. owns a small grocery store in Doun Pen Village in Kampong Cham Province. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to buy grocery goods to increase her inventory. Her husband, Mr. Chhoeurng Sithuon, is a recyclable materials collector who buys empty bottles, cans, plastic etc. and sells them to a recycling factory to earn his income. Mrs. Phally T. is 28 years old and the mother of two children. One child attends the local school and the youngest is four months old. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy grocery goods to increase her inventory.

loan.name: Nhor

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhor S. is a villager in Doun Pen Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a farmer who earns a little revenue by cultivating rice on her small piece of land. Her husband, Mr. Thoeung Thean, is a recyclable materials collector who uses the money to purchase empty bottles, cans, plastic, etc. to sell to a recycling factory for an income. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it; so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more recycling wastes to sell.

Mrs. Nhor S. is 39 years old and the mother of four children. One child is employed in a garment factory while two others are enrolled in the local school. The youngest child is only four years old. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy more recycling wastes to sell.

loan.name: Mahmadsaid

texts.ru: ÐœÐ°ÑˆÑ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ð² ÐœÐ°Ñ…Ð¼Ð°Ð´ÑÐ°Ð¸Ð´ Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒ Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ð° Ð”Ð¶Ð°Ð»Ð¾Ð»Ð»Ð¸Ð´Ð¸Ð½Ð¸ Ð Ð£Ð¼Ð¸. Ð’Ð¾Ð·Ñ€Ð°ÑÑ‚ 37 Ð»ÐµÑ‚. ÐŸÐ¾Ð»Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¸ 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Mahmadsaid M. lives in the Jaloluddini Rumi District. He is 37 years old and a professional ballet choreographer in the district's cultural center. In addition he also sells clothing at the market in the district center. He wants to increase sales by obtaining a loan. It is needed to develop the business, and also to respond to customer requests to expand inventory. The loan can be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Marieta

texts.ru: Ð¥ÑƒÐ´Ð¾Ð¹Ð±ÐµÑ€Ð´Ð¸ÐµÐ²Ð° ÐœÐ°Ñ€Ð¸ÐµÑ‚Ð° Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð¶Ð¸Ð²Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ðµ ÐšÑƒÑ€Ð³Ð°Ð½-Ñ‚ÑŽÐ±Ðµ. Ð—Ð°Ð¼ÑƒÐ¶ÐµÐ¼ , Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ñ‡ÐµÑ‚Ð²ÐµÑ€Ñ‹Ñ… Ð´ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹. ÐžÐ±Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ ÑÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð½ÐµÐµ. Ð Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð½Ð° Ñ€Ñ‹Ð½ÐºÐµ Ð² Ñ†ÐµÐ½Ñ‚Ñ€Ðµ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð°. Ð¢Ð¾Ñ€Ð³ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð¾Ð´ÐµÐ¶Ð´Ð¾Ð¹. Ð•Ð³Ð¾ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑŒÐ·ÑƒÐµÑ‚ÑÑ Ð±Ð¾Ð»ÑŒÑˆÐ¸Ð¼ ÑÐ¿Ñ€Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð¼. ÐÐ¾ Ð¾Ð½ Ñ…Ð¾Ñ‡ÐµÑ‚ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð°ÑÑÐ¾Ñ€Ñ‚Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐ½Ñ‚ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€Ð°. Ð”Ð»Ñ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð¾Ð½ Ð¾Ð±Ñ€Ð°Ñ‚Ð¸Ð»ÑÑ Ðº Ð½Ð°Ð¼. ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ Ð¿Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ 6 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Marieta H. lives in a city of Qurgan-tube. She is married and has four children. She has a secondary education and works at a market in the city center. She sells clothes. The business is profitable because goods are brought from Dushanbe, and customers are able to make purchases without leaving their locale. Marietaâ€™s clothes are very popular, but she wants to increase the assortment of goods. This is why she approached Kiva. She plans to repay the loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To increase goods assortment

loan.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda L. is married to Edgardo, a tricycle operator . The couple is blessed with three children: Mark Christian, 7; Ana Angel, 4; and John Patrick, 1. The family lives in a small village located along the mountainside and is far from the town proper of Ilagan, Isabela. Most of the villagers cultivate corn and rice to support themselves.
Hilda sells generic medicines in their neighborhood because there is no clinic in the area and drug stores are far away. She sells medicines for common problems such as stomachache, toothache, dizziness, headache, diarrhea, muscle pain, flu, cough, and fever. She has been in this business for six years.
Hilda is requesting a loan of Php7, 000 to expand her business. She plans to purchase additional medicines that are needed by her customers.
She also intends to use some of her loan to repair her husbandâ€™s motorcycle so he can continue his work and generate additional income for their daily needs. They also want to save money for the education of their children.

loan.use: To buy medicines

loan.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen M. is a 57-year-old widow with six children. In her youth she belonged to an average family because her parents had a pottery business. When her father died, they did not continue their business because they lacked the necessary knowledge to run it. At the age of 24, Helen married and started a family. Since her husband died, she has managed the fishing equipment he left. She personally sells the catch from their fishing boat in nearby municipalities.
Since she became a member of Paglaum MPC, Helen has been a member in good standing. She wants to obtain financial assistance from Paglaum MPC amounting to Php 20,000.00 for the purchase of new nets and to buy the fish catch of her neighbors so she can sell more fish to the nearby fish market. In the future, she dreams of renovating their house by setting aside some savings from the daily sales from her fish retail business.

loan.use: Purchase new nets and capital for fish buying

loan.name: Chhon's Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank consists of six members who reside in Lvea Sor Kandal Village in Kandal Province, each planning to use their share of the loan for different purposes. Elected by the members, Mrs. Chhon S., a 51 year-old-widow and mother of a child employed in a garment factory, is the group leader. Chhon is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivaT. both rice and vegetables to earn a living. As well, she is a vegetable seller.

Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it and so is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables to sell.

loan.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To buy more fishnets to support her husbandâ€™s fishing business.

loan.name: Sakun's Group

texts.en:
This three-member group from Battambang Province is led by Mrs. Sakun C., 48, a seller in the local market of produce including water-lilies, cabbage, tomatoes, and bean trees. Her husband, Mr. Saren Som, is a 54-year-old motorcycle taxi driver. Sakun is applying for a loan of $100 to buy more vegetables to sell and piglets to breed.

The other two other members are:

Mrs. Taingun M., 33, a vegetable seller who seeks a loan of $200 to enlarge her business;

Mrs. Mom T., a 41-year-old who makes a living selling shrimp and is requesting a $50 loan to buy additional shrimp.

loan.use: To buy more provisions to sell.

loan.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana C., 50 years old and married with seven children, lives in Benin City with her family. She has sold provisions and a local gin called Ogogoro for several years, and now hopes to expand her business through a loan to purchase more provisions and gin to sell. Christiana says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase more local gin and provisions to sell

loan.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is a simple vendor who lives in a small village of Barangay Lullutan Ilagan, Isabela, where people are disciplined and hardworking. Riding a ferry boat is the only means to get in and out of the village.
Daily, Juanita wakes up very early to catch the first ferry to the other side of the river and then she takes a tricycle to the public market where she purchases vegetables and other products to sell in her village. Using a basket to carry her products, Juanita then walks from house to house to sell her vegetables.
Juanita has always been a good borrower. She always pays on time, and she works hard to improve her business. She wants to use this loan to buy a tri bike (a bicycle with a carriage) for her house-to-house vending. This will not only help her move faster and easier but also to carry more items to sell in her community
She dreams of having a successful business, sending her children to college, and saving for her familyâ€™s future.

loan.use: additional working capital

loan.name: Sojida

texts.ru: ÐÐ¾ÑÐ¸Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð° Ð¡Ð¾Ð´Ð¶Ð¸Ð´Ð° Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð¶Ð¸Ð²Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ðµ Ð“Ð¸ÑÑÐ°Ñ€.Ð’Ð¾Ð·Ñ€Ð°ÑÑ‚ 32 Ð»ÐµÑ‚ .Ð—Ð°Ð¼ÑƒÐ¶ÐµÐ¼ , Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ð´Ð²Ð¾Ð¸Ñ… Ð´ÐµÑ‚ÐµÐ¹, Ñ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð½Ð° Ñ†ÐµÐ½Ñ‚Ñ€Ð°Ð»ÑŒÐ½Ð¾Ð¼ Ñ€Ñ‹Ð½ÐºÐµ Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ðµ. Ð¢Ð¾Ñ€Ð³ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð¾Ð´ÐµÐ¶Ð´Ð¾Ð¹. Ð’ Ð±Ð¸Ð·Ð½ÐµÑÐµ ÑƒÐ¶Ðµ 8 Ð»ÐµÑ‚. ÐŸÐ»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÑ€Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð¼ Ð½Ð° 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Sojida N. lives in the Gissar District. She is 32 years old, married, and has two children. She sells clothing in the district's central market. She has been in this business for 8 years already. She plans to receive a loan to be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene D. grew up in Butuan City, which is in the Caraga Region of the Philippines. She now lives in the town of Lopez Jaena in the Misamis Occidental province with her husband Severino and their three children. They met each other when they were working in Manila City. When they decided to marry, they agreed to live in Severinoâ€™s hometown. Arleneâ€™s primary income is from her â€œcarinderia,â€ a mini eatery. Severino is a carpenter.
Arlene is one of the pioneer Paglaum Coop members. She joined when the program was introduced in Lopez Jaena in 1997. She has taken out five loans with this group.
Arlene lives near Mindanao State University-Lopez Jaena, which offers classes from the primary grades through high school. Many of her customers are students, teachers, and fisherfolks. Now Arlene is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 ($325 USD) so she can buy supplies for her carinderia and add new menu items that her customers have requested.
Arlene is hoping that through this loan she can increase her income, enhance her carinderia, and purchase a door lock for the carinderia. She also wants to buy a refrigerator so she wonâ€™t have to rent a freezer from her neighbor anymore. The income from the carinderia is of great help to her family, especially in times when her husband has no work. Arlene is very thankful for Paglaum. It has improved the quality of her familyâ€™s life.

loan.use: To buy supplies for her eatery

location.town: Upper Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental

loan.name: Robiyua

Ð¢ÐµÐ¿ÐµÑ€ÑŒ Ð¾Ð½Ð° Ð¿Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ€Ð¾Ð¾Ð±Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ñ‚ Ð¿ÑƒÑ‚ÐµÐ¼ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚Ð°. Ð¡Ñ€Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð¼ Ð½Ð° 12 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².
texts.en:
Robiyua S. lives in the Gissar District. She is a widow, having lived without her husband for four years already. She started her business in clothing sales soon after his death. The business enables her to support her children. She has three young children, who are all going to school. Providing them with a good education requires her to work a lot. Now she plans to use a loan to increase sales. The loan term is 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette B. is 42 years old, married and has four children. Her husband Nino is a rice farmer from Sto. She is a CEV client who raises ducks and uses the proceeds from their sale to send her children to school and earn enough money to live on.
She started her business in 2006 with 350 ducks, using a CEV loan as start-up capital. She sells the eggs in her municipality and employs two part-time workers to help her run the business.
She is applying for a new loan, her second, to buy ducklings and food for them to eat. She wants more ducks so she can increase the number of eggs she sells to her customers.
â€œI really need this loan to increase my egg production. I am planning and desire to supply and soon become a big- time egg distributor, not just in our area but to nearby municipalities," she said. â€œI want to help my family live a quality life, I want my children to finish a degree in college, I want them able to realize their dreams, and I want good things for them even if it means to do hard work and strive more in this business," she added.
Jeanette is an active CEV client who is entitled to the insurance benefits, credit assistance and training our organization has provided for the last 10 years.

loan.use: purchase of ducklings and feed for them to eat

loan.name: Meriam

texts.en:
One of the coastal barrios in the town of Plaridel is the barangay Usocan, where a certain woman named Meriam A. lives. She is 46 years old and married to Juanito, a devoted and brave fisherman. The couple was blessed with two children and both of them have settled down.
Mr. Juanito once worked with their neighbor who had a fishing boat. He had a small share of the fishing income, but it was not enough for the whole family. Meriam happened to become a Paglaum Co-op member when one of their neighbors (a co-op member too) sold the couple Paglaumâ€™s programs and services five years ago. The couple was so thankful for Paglaum because they were granted enough money to purchase machinery for their own fishing boat. From then on, Meriam's husband no longer worked with their neighbor, but focused on his own fishing boat and has reaped their income from it. While her husband is focusing on fishing, Mrs. A. is also vending snacks, ice candy, ice, and bar-b-que in their neighborhood to provide additional income for the family. Bar- b-que is a kind of thinly sliced pork or any meat attached to a bamboo stick and grilled. It has a minimal selling price of only two to five pesos and is very affordable to the market.
Currently, the couple has acquired three unit motorized pump boats and is applying for a loan worth fifteen thousand pesos (P15,000.00) for the acquisition of another fishing boat which is bigger and better than what they have now. According to them, the bigger the boat is, the more it can fight big waves, can run through even during stormy season, and can transport and hold a number of huge fish caught at sea. An average of fifty kilos per day is their daily sales from one unit motorized pump boat, with an average of forty pesos (P40) selling price per kilo, depending on the type and variety of fish.
The couple was so grateful for Paglaum MPC because through the co-op they were able to build a partially concrete house. The couple hopes for more blessings to come as they faithfully maintain their Member In Good Standing status with the co-op and pay their loans on time with no trace of default. The family is dreaming of having a â€œlantsaâ€, a much bigger fishing boat with at least 20 workers so that they can fish from coast to coast in the future.

loan.use: Purchase motorboat for fishing

loan.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort D. is 39 years old. She is a wife and mother of kids together with two of her sisters' kids. Currently three of the kids are in school because the others have completed school. Comfort enjoys selling and has much experience in customer care. She has been selling beans and bags of maize for eight years to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock of beans and the bags of maize from the farmers. This saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. She wants to use the loan to buy beans and maize in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children in school. Comfort is a member of a community group called â€˜The Voice Trust Groupâ€™. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loan.use: To buy beans and bags of maize in bulk.

payment.comment: retraction of repayment id 10235734
retraction of repayment id 10235735

loan.name: Sryrith's Group

texts.en:
This three-member loan group is led by Mrs. Sryrith C., 23, a mother of one and a public gardens maintainer for a small private company in Battambang Province. She currently earns a salary of $80 per month while her husband, Mr. Sokha Ly, 26, works as a motorcycle taxi driver. Sryrith is seeking a loan of $400 to buy a grocery store for sale and a motorcycle to replace the old one.

The other two members are: Mrs. Ret T., a 54-year-old public gardens maintainer who is requesting a loan of $300 to buy groceries for her daughter to sell;

Mr. Hout P., 56, a construction worker who is applying for a $150 loan to purchase construction materials for use in his work.

All three borrowers live in Battambang Province.

loan.use: To buy a grocery store

loan.name: Austine Favour

texts.en: C., 33 years old and married with four children, has been a bookseller in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria for the past year. Because demand for her books is very high, she is requesting a loan to purchase more books to sell. C. says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more books to sell.

loan.name: Roman

texts.en:
Roman runs a small business selling toys in Belaya Tserkov. He has a vending facility in one of the local markets called â€œOberygâ€. He launched his small venture 4 years ago and has been growing it since then. Roman realizes one big advantage he has in this market - low competition in this sphere of trade. This factor has helped him considerably in expansion of his business--up to 15,000 Grivnas invested in turnover capital.

Romanâ€™s two sons are his testing experts. They always help him choose the best quality and saleable merchandise. This time Roman is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas to increase assorted inventory. We believe his hard work and determination will help Roman repay the current loan. Moreover, it will help him fulfill his long-term goal of starting a second business. He plans to offer transportation for market vendors traveling to wholesale centers to purchase additional stock.

loan.use: To increase assorted inventory

loan.name: Flor

texts.en:
Flor C. is 50 years old and the mother of six. Her husband is a farmer, and two of their children are away studying in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. Flor never stops investing in and improving her business.
In 1997, she started her hog-raising company with six piglets, using a CEV loan as start-up capital. She sells her output to hog buyers in the municipality of Sto.NiÃ±o. With this income, she has been able to renovate her house and pay her family's daily expenses.
She is requesting a new loan to buy additional livestock and animal feed. She believes that she could definitely increase her income if she could buy more hogs. â€œThe demand for meat is extremely high, so I should grow more hogs to benefit from that demand," she said. â€œ If I get my requested loan, I could do more in my businessâ€, she added.
By joining CEV, she gets the insurance benefits of our program as well as credit assistance and training.

loan.use: To buy more pigs and animal feed

loan.name: 16-Nam Ngáº¡n Ii Group

texts.en:
Loan Group 16 consists of five poor women, all of whom live in Nam Ngan II street, Nam Ngan Ward, Thanh Hoa City. Thanh Hoa City is the provincial capital of Thanh Hoa province, one of the poorest provinces in Vietnam, and is located approximately 150 kilometers south of Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam.

Mrs. Ngan Dao Thi is the lead borrower of the group. Her husband, Mr.Khoi Vu Viet, is retired. They have two children who have left school and are now part of the workforce. Her family farms a small plot of land and primarily grows rice. Additionally, she raises pigs and chickens.

Mrs Ngan Dao Thai has borrowed once before from the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women and repaid that loan in full and on time. She will use her share of the loan to buy more pigs and chickens and she will also start making bricks for sale.

The loan will be split equally among all five borrowers with each member of the group borrowing 1,626,900 Vietnamese Dong, or just under US$ 100. The other borrowers in the group will use their share of the loan as follows: *Mrs. Duc Le Thi is borrowing money to buy and raise chickens, ducks, and pigs. *Mrs. Van Le Thi is borrowing money to buy and raise chickens and pigs. *Mrs. Vinh Le Thi is borrowing money to buy large quantities of sticky rice which she will then sell in smaller quantities to her customers in the early morning. She is also borrowing money to buy and raise chickens and pigs. *Mrs. Kim Le Thi is borrowing money to buy dry goods for re-sale. She is also borrowing money to buy fertilizer and rice.

loan.use: chickens, pigs, ducks, sticky rice, dry goods, etc.

loan.name: Alovuddin

texts.en:
Alovuddin D. is a high school teacher. He is 52 years old, is married and has six children. Alovuddin works in a school and also raises livestock. He purchases calves, fattens them up and resells them. He has been in this business for 10 years. This business is a good fit for a rural area and he has everything necessary to run it. Alovuddin would like to take out a loan in order to increase his livestock count and to purchase two additional calves. He will pay back the loan over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase two calves

loan.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine Archibong sells provisions and drinks. She sells in retail to her customers. She is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She hopes to stock her shop with more provisions and drinks because during the festive season, the demand for her goods will be high. She needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loan.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mrs. Seng S. is a 37-year-old who makes a living growing vegetables which she sells 3 months after planting at the market to earn income, making around $2 per day. She is married with three young children, all of who still live at home whilst her husband, Mr. Shavdy Horm, 26, is a local builder who has several workers for providing services to customers for income and lives in Battambang Province.

Seng is requesting a loan of US$ 500 for her husband to use for enlarging his investment and paying workers' salaries.

loan.use: to enlarge their business

loan.name: Chika

texts.en:
Chika C. is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions and drinks in her community. She started this business in 2006.
She hopes for the loan amount of N70, 000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She hopes to stock her shop with more provisions and drinks so that she can meet the demands of her customers, and not lose them to competitors.
Chika says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loan.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina is married and has no children. She sells clothing and shoes at the central market in Ordzhonikidze. She started her business six years ago. Antonina believes that offering high quality products and having exceptional customer service is a win-win strategy for both her customers and herself. The best proof of this is her clients that keep coming back to purchase more goods. With her business, Antonina's gross income increased to 3800 UAH per month.

Antonina is requesting a loan of 2,100 UAH to purchase more clothing and shoes. She hopes to sell it during the upcoming winter season and increase her profit. Note: this is a short term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loan.use: to purchase more clothing and shoes

loan.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe A. is 56 years old and the mother of five. She and her huband are rice farmers, and have been in this trade ever since Fe inherited a three-hectare plot from her mother. Her husband cultivates the land it, planting rice for his family to consume and more to sell on the open market. During harvest season, Fe sells a portion of their crop to traders in their town. The profit they make covers their expenses and helps pay for their children's schooling.
Fe is applying for a loan to buy six bags of fertilizer and two quarts of insecticide. â€œI need this loan to increase the yield of my farm and augment my income," she said.
Mrs. A. is a loyal CEV client who has benefited from our insurance program along with the training and credit assistance we provide.

loan.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide

loan.name: Wilhelmina

texts.en: Wilhelmina A. started her local restaurant twenty years ago in Ashaiman, where she lives. Since then, she has become one of the popular food vendors in her neighborhood. She is now 56 years old and married, with three children who are currently in school. She serves many kinds of local dishes like fufu, rice balls, banku, and ampesi among others. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, and eaten with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is eaten with hot pepper or soup. Ampesi is a boiled plantain or yam and it is eaten with any stew. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. Wilhelmina hopes to use part of her proceeds to finance her children's education. She is a member of the community group called The Voice Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and support one another to repay. Wilhelmina is in the photograph taken during her group meeting.

loan.use: To purchase more raw materials for her restaurant business.

payment.comment: retraction of repayment id 10235736
retraction of repayment id 10235737

loan.name: Ismat

Ð¡Ñ‚Ð°Ñ€ÑˆÐ°Ñ Ð´Ð¾Ñ‡ÑŒ ÑƒÐ¶Ðµ Ð²Ð·Ñ€Ð¾ÑÐ»Ð°Ñ Ð¸ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ñ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾Ð±Ñ‹ Ð´Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐµÐ¹ Ð¾Ð±Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ Ð¾Ð½ Ð´Ð¾Ð»Ð¶ÐµÐ½ Ð¼Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾, Ð¼Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ñ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ.
texts.en:
Ismat V. lives in the city of Vahdat. He is married and has four children. His oldest daughter is now grown, and Ismat has to work a lot to help her obtain education. He drives a shuttle bus â€œGazelâ€ on the Dushanbe-Vahdat route. He has been in the transportation business for 10 years. To increase profitability and decrease transportation cost, Ismat wants to install gas equipment. This will help retain many return clients. In order to install this equipment, he needs a loan of $1200, repayable within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Installation of gas equipment

loan.name: Mrs. Noeurn Peang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of ten members, is located in Prasat Village in Kampong Cham Province and they plan to use the loan that they have obtained for various purposes. Mrs. Noeurn P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land used to cultivate rice to earn her income. With the rice revenue, she not only cannot support her household, but she also cannot afford to buy another piece of land to cultivate more rice. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions within a few months. Mrs. Noeurn P. is 60 years old, a widow and the mother of nine children. Two of her children are employed in a garment factory. Five others are laborers and the others are enrolled in the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKâ€™s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodiaâ€™s poor. This system allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKâ€™s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy a piece of land to cultivate rice.

loan.name: Samach

texts.en:
Mrs. Samach S., 23, is a local tailor who took this up over 3 years ago for income to support family, especially for her one young childâ€™s food. She can earn approximately $5 each day and her husband, Mr. Shot So, 33, is a motorcycle taxi driver who always leaves home in the early morning to pick up passengers for money.
Samach needs to ask for $1,100 loans to use as capital for local transferring money service for her customers from place to place and charge fee. The family lives in Banteay Meanchey province.

loan.use: to use as capital for local transferring money service

loan.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is 48 years old and a married mother of four children. Her children are currently in school. Beatrice sells frozen food in the local market to support her family. She says demand is high, but she does not have the capital required to meet the demand. She wants to use the loan to buy more cartons of frozen food, so she can earn enough income to support her children's education. She is a member of the group called Angels. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loan.use: The purchase of cartons of frozen food like fish, chicken, mutton, etc.

loan.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene S. is a 34-year old mother of two children whose husband is a farmer from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. The entire family is engaged in the business of farming.
Arlene also raises hogs. She started her project in 2007 with only one sow using a loan from CEV. She manages her business by herself and is able to make a profit and support all of her family's needs. In an interview she said, â€œI was able to earn Php 48,000 for the piglets I sold, and the money I earned definitely goes to our family budget as income," she added.
She is requesting a new loan to buy feed for her animals. The main problem her business has faced is getting enough animal feed, and this loan will help her meet that goal.
Arlene has been a client of CEV for the last two years. We have provided her with credit, training and insurance.

loan.use: To buy animal feed

loan.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey I. is group leader of the four members who all live in Tro Mukh Ti Muoy village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land used to cultivate rice to earn her living. Since her plantation is going well, she wants to also cultivate rice during the dry season. Unfortunately, she cannot plant because she does not have enough money. Therefore, Mrs. Srey I. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice, fertilizers and pesticide. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. S. Sophy, is an ice-cream seller. Mrs. Srey I. is 36 years old and the mother of three children. Two are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans and one has a monthly payment loan. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMKâ€™s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodiaâ€™s poor. This system allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMKâ€™s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To buy rice, fertilizers and pesticide.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To add new clothing to her inventory.

loan.name: Neang

texts.en: Mrs. Neang Y. is a farmer who now lives in Trapaing Ampil village in Kampong Cham Province. She owns a small piece of land used to cultivate rice to earn her living. She has very little income for her family. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start her cattle breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Neang Y. is a 48-year-old widow and the mother of five children. Two are laborers, one stays at home to do housework and the others are enrolled in the local school.

loan.use: To buy a cow to start her cattle breeding business.

loan.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida G. is a 33-year old mother with two children. Her husband is an electrician from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato, but the couple could hardly send their two children to school before she went into business.
Today, Leinida manages a hog-raising business in their yard. She and her husband jointly run the business, and devote their earnings to building a bright future for their children. She started their business with only one sow, and was able to make a profit for every batch of piglets they sold. The earnings she gets from her animals is used mainly to support her family needs.
Leonida is requesting a loan to buy animal feed for the hogs. â€œI need to feed my hogs well to increase their weight. They are commercial hogs so I have to put a lot of money into food for them," she said.
She hopes for a good future for her children so that they can finish their studies and get good, stable jobs. When she joined CEV, Lenoida said, â€œPart of my dream is to have a profitable business that would uplift us from poverty. Now, I am starting to realize that dream. Through CEV, I can expand my business. With the credit assistance and training they provide to their clients, I could do it by faith. I could change our lives," she added.

loan.use: To buy animal feed

loan.name: Kimsroy

texts.en: Mrs. Kimsroy T. is a 43-year-old widow and now lives in Trapaing Ampil village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a fish seller. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. However, she faces an obstacle because she currently cannot sell far from her house. Therefore, Mrs. Kimsroy T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. She has four children who are employed in a garment factory.

loan.use: To buy a motorbike for her business.

loan.name: Bertha

texts.en: Bertha A. is 54 years old. She is married and the mother of five children. Currently two of her children are in school. She sells charcoal, maize, and bags of gari in her local community. Charcoal is a very popular cooking fuel in most traditional Ghanaian homes. Bertha buys her supplies in the villages and sells them to her customers. She has supported two of her children through school with income from her business. With the loan, she wants to buy more supplies to serve her customers. She hopes the loan will enable her to save more to support her other children through school. She would be very grateful for that support. Bertha belongs to the trust group called Angels. Members of this group agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loan.use: For the purchase of more supplies of charcoal, bags of maize, and gari.

loan.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
At the young age of 26, Evelyn C. began finding her niche in the world of business. She is a single mother from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato, who pushed herself to be strong despite the many challenges she encountered.
Sitting in her favorite chair in their living room, she confidently shared her experiences with early motherhood. In an interview she said, â€œlife has never been easy for me, especially now that I have a huge responsibility to my child. I have to wake up early every morning at the same time to earn a living and survive."
She now runs a hog-raising business. She started her project with only one sow, but now earns a profit for every piglet she sells. This profit goes to pay family expenditures, a big help in covering her family's needs. She is requesting a loan to buy feed for her hogs.
Her youthful exuberance drove her to join CEV. Now she has access to the credit assistance, training and insurance benefits that our organization provides.

loan.use: To buy feed for her pigs

loan.name: Pheakdey

texts.en: Mr. Pheakdey O. is a 45-year-old who sells gasoline for wholesale or retail in front of his house to his customers across the street in the area of Poypet Commune. His wife, Mrs. Sarin Pech, is 44 years old and helps her husbandâ€™s work and also lives with one son who is a minor and living at home. Both currently earn approximately $11 per day for income to sustain their familyâ€™s food. Pheakdey applied for a $1,000 loan to purchase gasoline stores for resale. They live in Banteay Meanchey Province.

loan.use: to purchase gasoline stores for resale

loan.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort O. is 43 years old, married, and the mother of two children. One child is currently in school, while the other has completed school. Comfort is a distributor and a supplier of ice cream and yogurt at a very busy market in Tema, where she lives. She takes delivery from the manufacturers and supplies to retailers. Comfort has been in this business for the past 2 years and has rich experience in the field. She requests the loan to buy more supplies of ice cream, and deep freezers to store her products. She believes with the loan she would be able to support her child in school. Comfort would be grateful for the assistance provided by the loan. She belongs to the community group called Morning Star Trust Group; members in this group provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: The purchase of bulk supplies of ice cream and yogurt.

loan.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria A. sells drinks to people in her community. She is 31 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City with her family. Gloria is a LAPO client and hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loan.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov C. is a villager in Ta Sean village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a Khmer cake seller. Her husband, Mr. Seng Sokheang, repairs cassette players. He now has a lot of customers but does not have enough cassette player equipment to meet his customers' needs. Therefore, Mrs. Pov C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more equipment for her husband's business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. She is 42 years old and the mother of three children. Two are attending the local school and the youngest is seven moths old.

loan.use: To buy cassette player equipment to repair customers' machines.

loan.name: Itohan

texts.en: Itohan N. is a fashion designer. She makes lovely designs for her customers. She needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell. Itohan is 23 years old and married with a child. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell

loan.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace A. is a trader in the local market of Tema in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana, where she lives with her family. She is a 38-year-old married woman, with three children who are currently in school. She has been selling maize grain, plantain, cassava and other food from a table in the market for the past eight years. She does not have sufficient working capital to run the business, which hampers her business progress. With the loan, she wants to purchase increased stock to expand the business. She believes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to care for her children in school. She would be grateful for that assistance. She belongs to the group called â€˜Morning Starâ€™ Trust Group; members in this group provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: The purchase of increased stock of cassava, fresh tomatoes, onions, beans, maize, dried fish etc.

loan.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa D., the 54-year old mother of eight, is a high school graduate and entrepreneur from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato.
Duck raising has been her only source of income. She started her project in the year 2000, with 300 ducks. Using a small loan as starting capital, she has slowly gained the trust of her customers, who come from nearby neighborhoods to buy all the eggs and ducks she can produce.
She now employs two workers to help care for her ducks, thereby creating jobs for others while earning money for herself. Josefa is requesting a new loan from CEV to buy feed. With this, she will be able to sustain and improve her business.
CEV helped her buy 350 ducklings in previous loan cycles. This has been very helpful to her and her family, considering that this is their sole means of support. In addition to credit and training, she also gets the insurance that CEV provides to all of its clients.

loan.use: To buy feed for her ducks

loan.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano S. lives in the Gissar district. She is married and has two children. She works at the Gissar central market and has been selling clothes for 14 years. Her business helps customers buy goods at affordable prices without leaving their locale. She wants to obtain a 12-month loan in order to expand goods inventory. This will help her increase goods turnover and attract new clients.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increasing goods turnover

loan.name: Deap

texts.en:
Mrs. Deap O. is 38 years old. She sells rice and food to students who study in Salapejon School and she lives in Banteay Meanchey province. She sells only in the morning, earning around $7 a day, which she had done since 2007. She cares for one child and is married to Mr. Sopaiy Ly, 38, who is a motorcycle taxi driver.

Recently, Sopaiy has been feeling upset with his old motorcycle that often has problems. He discussed with his wife applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new one and, with the rest, to decorate the house. (Mrs. Deap's husband is pictured, because she was not available.)

loan.use: To purchase a new motorcycle

loan.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is a 32-year-old trader. She is married with two children. She has been selling used clothes in the local market of Tema for seven years. With income from her business, Florence supports her children in junior and senior high school. Her major business challenge over the years has to do with funds to scale up the business. She has lots of marketing experience and is very confident that the loan would enable her to achieve remarkable business progress. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothes to serve her customers. She hopes to save enough to support her children until they complete school. She belongs to the group called â€˜Morning Starâ€™ Trust Group; members in this group provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: The purchase of bales of used clothes.

loan.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret O. is 36 years old and married to Mr. O.. They have five children. She has a store where she sells provisions and foodstuffs. She has been in this business for a long time. Margaret is a LAPO client and needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loan.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is a 38-year-old trader. She is married with one child; she also cares for her sister's child. She has been selling used clothes in the local market of Tema for 2 years. With income from her business, Florence supports the two children in school. Her major business challenge over the years has to do with funds to scale up the business. She has lots of marketing experience and is very confident that the loan would enable her to achieve remarkable business progress. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothes to serve her customers. She hopes to save enough to support her children through school. She belongs to the group called â€˜Morning Starâ€™ Trust Group; members in this group provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy more bales of used clothes.

loan.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience G. is a mother of two children who are currently in school. She is a 30-year-old trader. She trades in lace materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. For lack of adequate working capital, Patience can buy only small amounts of lace materials to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the next level. With the loan, she wants to purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with quality educations. Patience belongs to the community group called Morning Star Trust group. The group members guarantee a loan through a repayment pledge and support one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk

loan.name: Susette

texts.en:
Susette A. is a 29-year-old married woman blessed with three children. She is a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PDP-LP) and belongs to Lovely 1 Center in cluster 7 presently residing at Unidos, Plaridel, Misamis, Ocidental. She took out a loan for a small sari-sari store project. Every day she gained P300, but this was not enough for the daily basic needs of her family and for the education of her three children.
She also has secondary project, which is a cocolumber, located at Calamba, Misamis, Occidental. This project was managed by her husband but did not succeed due to the low demand for these supplies. Presently, her husband drives a private dump truck earning P200 per day. Itâ€™s a big help in their family but still insufficient for their basic necessities.
Susette is now asking for a loan of P20,000 to provide additional capital for her sari-sari store, particularly for the purchase of assorted canned goods, spices, toiletries, rice and many other items. This additional capital will surely have a return of at least 300 per day.
Susette has a simple dream for her family: to become a successful business woman in her sari-sari store, for her children to finish their studies, and to have a happy family.

loan.use: Purchase of Assorted Grocery Items

loan.name: Airen

texts.en: Airen O. is 34 years old and still single. She lives in Benin City. She needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell in this festive period. She travels to the Onitsha main market in Anambra State to purchase sarongs to sell in Benin City. Airen has no store, but she hawks the sarongs along the major streets of Benin City. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loan.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita A. G. is 32 years old, married, and the mother of one child who is currently in school. She lives with her family in Tema in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana. She is a trader who has been trading in lace clothes, women's slippers, and dressing bags for the past five years. She requests a loan to augment her working capital to buy more stock to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to earn more income to support her family. Rita is a member of a community group called â€œMorning Starâ€ Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy bales of lace clothes, dressing bags, and slippers

loan.name: Maristela

texts.en:
Mrs. Maristela Sugano B., commonly known as â€œTilayâ€, is a member of Mangrove 1 Center, Danao, Plaridel, Mis.Occ. Maristela is 27 years old now. Her husband is Joy B., from Cotabato. She is a secondary graduate, and she has also completed her first semester in a vocational school. The couple is blessed with 2 beautiful girls, and a new baby is on the way.
The familyâ€™s main source of income is fish vending. Tilayâ€™s husband is also helping her sell fish to the market. Their average daily income from fish vending is five hundred pesos (P500.00) per day. Her husbandâ€™s other source of income comes from his work at LANSA, which is done at night. LANSA is a big fishing boat that needs 40 workers. Most of the time, LANSA workers earn at least two thousand pesos (P2,000.00) per month.
Tilay is applying a for loan amounting to twenty thousand pesos (P20,000.00) for the purpose of buying additional fishing accessories, such as a fishing net with an estimated cost of 10,000 pesos. The rest of the loan proceeds will be applied as revolving capital for the purchase of fish from the fishermen.
Tilay and her husband dream of acquiring an engine for their boat so that they can have their own fishing business and increase their income. They would also like to finish construction on their new house, and they hope that all of their children can finish their studies, the only legacy they may able to give to them.

loan.use: Purchase fishing nets and other related accessories

loan.name: Sophal's Group

texts.en:
There are three members applying for this loan. Mrs. Sophal P. is a 28-year-old who has sold second-hand clothing in the local market since 2006. She is running the business very well with much experience. She has one child and is married to Mr. Vanny Heng, 26, a motorcycle taxi driver who earns approximately $5 a day. Sophal hopes to enlarge her business so she decided to ask for a $200 loan to purchase more used clothing for sale.

The other two members are Mrs. Peun S., 58, who sells Khmer cakes and seeks a loan of $125 to buy ingredients, and Mrs. Kveub S., 30, a good housewife who relies on her husbandâ€™s income and asks for a $150 loan to improve her husbandâ€™s business. They all live in Battambang Province. (Mrs. Sophal, Mrs. Peun and Mrs. Kveub's husband are pictured, because Mrs. Kveub was not available that time.)

loan.use: To purchase more used clothing

loan.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard O. is 46 years old and married with four children. Richard is a baker by trade. He bakes meat pies and distributes to schools around his community. Richard has problems with the local oven he uses to bake, so he needs an electrical oven for baking to enable him to meet the demands of his customers. He needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase an electrical oven to bake more meat pies to sell. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase an electrical oven to bake more meat pies to sell

loan.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes B. is 33 years old, married, and the mother of two children. Her children are currently in school. For the past 10 years, Agnes has sold frozen foods in the local market to support her family. She says demand for fish is high but she does not have enough capital to meet the demand. She wants to use the loan to buy more cartons of frozen foods, so she can earn enough income to support her children's education. She is a member of the group called Angels. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods to sell.

loan.name: Felicita

texts.en:
Mrs. Felicita Bullanday A., commonly known as â€œManding Felingâ€, is seventy years old. She lives at Sibula, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. Though she is now in her old age, she is still physically fit and healthy. She is a long time Sari-Sari Store owner; her store is located within their community and is accessible to the neighborhood. Felicita and her husband are members of the Senior Citizens group wherein they have the chance to receive discounts on medicine, transportation, and many other expenses. They are blessed with 7 siblings who are now married. Felicitaâ€™s husband works on their own farm, cultivating and planting different kinds of vegetables as well as bananas and other fruit trees. He also receives an honorarium of P3,500 per month for serving as a pastor in their church.
Based on her previous loan history, Felicita is a member in good standing (MIGS) with no history of defaults for the past 9 loan cycles. She is presently working on a loan application for twenty thousand pesos (P20,000.00) for the purchase of additional grocery stock such as rice, canned goods, toiletries and many other related items. Her daily income from her Sari-Sari store is estimated to be five hundred pesos (P500.00).
Felicita wishes to increase and expand her business so that she can save enough money to concrete her small Sari-Sari Store and protect the groceries from being eaten by mice. According to Felicita, her business is already her life and her heart is in it.
Felicita is an active member of Golden Hope Center, a PDP-LP, microfinance unit of Paglaum MPC. She is so grateful for Paglaum because it provides holistic development support through its trainings, teachings, savings programs, and insurance.

loan.use: Purchase of additional grocery items

loan.name: Sharofat

texts.en:
Sharofat U. lives in the Gissar District. She lives in one of the district's remote areas, and every day travels to the center for work. She is a dynamic woman and supports her family. For 12 years she has had a business in sales. She sells clothing at the central market. Having found out about our organization, she decided to take out a loan to use to increase sales. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increasing Sales

loan.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is 50 years old. She is married and the mother of five children. Currently two of her children are in school. She has sold charcoal and salt in her local community for 4 years now. Charcoal is a very popular cooking fuel in most traditional Ghanaian homes. Rose buys her supply of charcoal and salt from the villages and sells at retail to her customers. She depends on her business to support her children in school. With the loan, she wants to buy more charcoal and bags of salt to increase her business. She hopes the loan will enable her to save enough money to support her children through school. She would be very grateful for that support. Rose belongs to the trust group called Morning Star. Members in this group agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loan.name: Loveth

texts.en: Loveth sells provisions and drinks. She is 33 years old and married with 3 children. Loveth is a LAPO client. She hopes to expand her business with more provisions and drinks to sell. She hopes for the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She hopes to make more profits during the festive seasons.

loan.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loan.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty A. is 30 years old and married to Mr. A.. They have 3 children. Beauty has a bar where she sells pepper soup and all kinds of drinks, to custumers that patronize her. Beauty hopes to expand her business. She needs the loan in the amount of N102,000 to purchase more pepper soup ingredients and drinks to sell. Her bar is usually open from 4pm-10pm daily. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase pepper soup ingredients and drinks to sell

loan.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is married and has three children. She resides with her family in Tema-Ashaiman in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. She is 38 years old. She runs a clothing shop and for the past five years, she has sold ladies' and children's clothing such as blouses and skirts, lingerie, and underwear. She needs a loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase a large quantity of high-quality clothing to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance. She is a member of the group called Morning Star. Members of this group agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To upgrade her clothing inventory.

loan.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda F. is the mother of two children who are currently in school. She is a 32-year-old trader. She trades in lace materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. Because she lacks adequate working capital, Matilda can buy only a small amount of material, which she sells through hawking. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business by purchasing lace materials and textiles in bulk. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with quality educations. Matilda belongs to the community group called Saints Trust group. The group members guarantee a loan through repayment pledges and support one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk

loan.name: Nazokat

texts.ru: Ð“Ð°ÑŽÑ€Ð¾Ð²Ð° ÐÐ½Ð·ÑƒÑ€Ð°Ñ‚ Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ½Ð¸Ñ†Ð° Ð“Ð¸ÑÐ°Ñ€ÑÐºÐ¾Ð³Ð¾ Ñ€Ð°Ð¹Ð¾Ð½Ð°. Ð—Ð°Ð¼ÑƒÐ¶ÐµÐ¼ , Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ð¾Ð´Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ñ€ÐµÐ±ÐµÐ½Ðº. Ð’Ð¾Ð·Ñ€Ð°Ñ 35 Ð»ÐµÑ‚. Ð¢Ð¾Ñ€Ð³Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ‡ÐºÐ° Ð½Ð° ÐºÐ¾Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð¹ Ð¾Ð½Ð° Ñ€Ð°Ð±Ð¾Ñ‚Ð°ÐµÑ‚ Ð°Ñ€ÐµÐ½Ð´ÑƒÐµÐ¼Ð°Ñ .ÐŸÐ¾ÑÐ»Ðµ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ , ÐµÑÐ»Ð¸ Ð´ÐµÐ»Ð° Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð²ÐµÑ€Ð½ÑƒÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ð¾Ð½Ð° Ð¿Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ€ÑƒÐµÑ‚ ÐºÑƒÐ¿Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÑÐ¾Ð±ÑÑ‚Ð²ÐµÐ½Ð½Ð¾Ðµ Ð¼ÐµÑÑ‚Ð¾.
texts.en:
Nazokat G. lives in the Gissar District. She is married and has one child. She is 35 years old. For the past five years she has been selling children's clothing. The goods are transported from the city of Dushanbe. She has many customers because she sells at such low prices. She decided to use a loan to increase sales. The loan will be repaid over 12 months. She currently rents her market stall, but if the business develops well after she receives the loan, she plans to buy her own space.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increase Sales

loan.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary O. is 50 years old and married with 7 children. She and her family live in Benin City. She sells second hand clothes and shoes to those who cannot afford to buy new ones. She is a LAPO client. She barely satisfies her customersâ€™ demands because she has little money to finance her business. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more second hand clothes and shoes to sell. She says "thank you" to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more second hand clothes and shoes to sell

loan.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria T., a 38-year-old trader, is married with three children. All her children are currently in school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family. Victoria supports her husband in providing for the household through the sale of used clothing. She has been in this business for the past five years. In Ghana, brand new clothes are very expensive, so selling used clothing has created opportunities for many women. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children's future and also to rent a store in which to trade. She is member of the group called Saints. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy more bales of used clothing.

loan.name: Liberty

texts.en: Liberty O. is 38 years old and married with 2 children. He and his family live in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Liberty learned how to make furniture for 6 years before starting his own business in 1992. He is a LAPO client and needs the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more woods and materials for making furniture. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase woods and materials for furniture making

loan.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience A. is 30 years old, married, and the mother of one child. Her child is eight years old and is currently in school. For the last year, Patience has sold frozen foods in the local market to support her family. She says demand for fish is high but she does not have sufficient capital to meet the demand. She wants to use the loan to buy more cartons of frozen foods, so she can earn enough income to support her child's education. She is a member of the group called Saints. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods to sell.

loan.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel O. is 24 years old and single. He sells frozen foods like chicken, fish and turkey. He is a LAPO client. Daniel has a cool room where he sells his frozen foods. The festive season is fast approaching and the demand for his frozen foods will be high. Daniel hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. He says "thank you" to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loan.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes A. is 42 years old. She is married and the mother of five children. Currently two of her children are in school. She has been a retailer of charcoal, cassava, maize and salt in her local community for 10 years now. Charcoal is a very popular cooking fuel in most traditional Ghanaian homes. Agnes buys her supplies from the villages and sells them at retail to her customers. She depends on her business to support her children in school. With the loan, she wants to buy more supplies to serve her customers. She hopes the loan will enable her to save more to support her children in school. She would be very grateful for that support. Agnes belongs to the trust group called Saints. Members in this group agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy more supplies of charcoal and bags of maize.

loan.name: Abdulla

texts.en:
G. Abdulla is 43 years of age. Since he was young, his father taught him to work on the land where together they produced wheat, corn and different kinds of vegetables. This type of business constitutes the economic base of the settlers of Shahrituz due to the characteristic botany of the zone. For ten years, G. has been dedicated to the production of wheat, onions and potatoes as his main economic activity. This activity has permitted his family to move forward. His wife is a housewife.
At present, the cultivation of the crop that he is producing is of a low quality due to the fact that the land needs chemical fertilizers to improve the performance of the soil. Thus, Abdulla is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1200 USD) that he is willing to repay in 12 months. Abdulla is counting on your help. He deeply appreciates the support that you are giving to him, and promises to repay the loan with accuracy in time.

loan.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loan.name: Goddey

texts.en: Goddey O. is single and he is 26 years old. He sells frozen foods and he has a cool room from where he sells them. Goddey wants to purchase more frozen foods to enable him to meet the demands of his customers. He hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. He is a LAPO client. Goddey says "thank you" to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loan.name: Mawusi

texts.en: Mawusi K. is 46 years old. She is married with four children who are currently in school. She sells food such as cassava, plantain, and maize in the local market of Tema where she lives. Since she has been selling for the past year, she has lots of selling experience to win customers. Mawusi is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to provide her children with quality educations for their future careers. She wants to use the loan to buy increased stock of cassava to prepare cassava dough, and bags of maize, to serve her customers. She is a member of the community group called Saints Trust Group. In this group members assist one another and provide support in handling repayment. She would be grateful for the assistance.

loan.use: To buy increased stock of cassava and and maize.

loan.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn O. is 32 years old and married with 3 children. She and her family live in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Evelyn sells foodstuffs and she has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. Evelyn appreciates the efforts of Kiva lenders in eradicating poverty. She says "thank you" to all that made this loan possible.

loan.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loan.name: Enyonam

texts.en: Enyonam F. is a wife and mother of five children who are currently in school. She is a 40-year-old trader who trades in charcoal and bags of gari. Charcoal is a very popular cooking fuel in many traditional Ghanaian homes. She has been in this business for the past 3 years. Through her business, she has supported two of her children through senior high school. Enyonam obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Tema and sells it at retail to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more charcoal and bags of gari to increase her stock. She believes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to provide for the educational needs of her children. She belongs to the community group called Morning Star Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another and provide support to one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal and bags of gari.

loan.name: Kawthar

texts.en: Kawthar S. is a 45 year-old woman living in Bar Elias in the Bekaa valley. A mother of three, Kawthar started working from home as a tailor in 1985. Being a very creative woman, she began to sell homemade souvenir gifts. As more and more clients requested her products, Kawthar soon opened her own workshop. Today she is asking for $1000 to buy inventory to produce more gifts and increase her sales.

loan.use: To buy supplies to meet customer demand for her tailored goods.

loan.name: SafiÃ©tou

texts.fr: Madame SafiÃ©tou C. est une brave commerÃ§ante , elle habite le quartier populaire de KandÃ© BanÃ©to. GrÃ¢ce Ã son commerce elle soutient son mari pour entretenir leur cinq enfants. Elle sollicite ce prÃªt pour renforcer son stock et augmenter son bÃ©nÃ©fice.La pÃ©riode est propice avec les fÃªtes de Tabaski et de fin d'annÃ©e.
texts.en:
Mrs. Safietou C. is an enterprising business woman. She lives in the popular district of Kande Baneto. With her business she is able to assist her husband in the raising of her five children. She is requesting this loan to increase her stock which will raise her income. This is an opportune time for business with the Tabaski (Muslim celebration) and the New Year holidays.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Commerce

loan.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita K. is 42 years old. She is a wife and mother of three children. Currently all the children are in school. Selling for the past ten years, she has gained lots of experience in her business. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock of maize from the farmers. This saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at a higher price. She wants to use the loan to buy maize in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to save enough money to sponsor her children's education. Rita is a member of a community group called â€˜Angels Trust Groupâ€™. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loan.use: To buy maize in bulk to sell to her customers.

loan.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence E. is 42 years old and married with 3 children. She started this business in 2002. She travels to Delta State in Nigeria to purchase local gin (ogogoro) to sell to retailers in Benin City. She is a LAPO client. She needs the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more local ogogoro to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders and that they should keep up the good work.

loan.use: To purchase more local gin (ogogoro) to sell

loan.name: Bekmurod

texts.en:
K. Bekmurod, 48, is an exceptionally responsible father. He's been farming since he was a young man; work that he likes. He needs better tools to cultivate his land, though, because he can only plant maize now with difficulty.
Bekmurod worries day and night about his children's education; they're the reason for his sweat and toil.
Due to the upcoming season, he wants to sow wheat, potatoes and onions. For this purpose, he requests $1000 USD for the term of 12 months. He wants to buy seeds, mineral fertilizer and also some new tools. Thanks to this loan, he will be able to expand his business and better provide for his family. With your help this will be possible.

loan.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loan.name: Nurulo
